Title: SleepOut 2 HelpOut

Description:
Crawley Open House has been on the front line serving the homeless and
vulnerable of Crawley and West Sussex for 26 years. They operate a 24 bed high
support hostel, a busy drop-in day centre open 365 days a year, 4 move-on
houses and a community outreach team. They cover a huge swathe of West and Mid
Sussex – there is no Horsham Open House, Haywards Heath Open House or East
Grinstead Open House….

 

Last year they managed to resettle around 60% of hostel residents to
somewhere more appropriate and permanent. There were over 24,000 support
appointments for residents, day centre users and those staying on the streets.
No-one locally does more to stand alongside those who have fallen or are
falling through the cracks in society, for whatever reason.

 

Crawley Open House are a medium-sized independent charity and rely
heavily on the generosity of local Trusts, places of worship, schools,
individuals and companies. They receive some statutory funding but are working
hard to diversify their income streams so as not to be too dependent on it, in
an uncertain political and economic climate.

 

They are about to start a building project to create a new day centre
built around a life-skills and employability workshop for the homeless and
vulnerable. They have raised around three quarters of the money required, and
are busy fundraising for the rest.

They have remained open throughout the Coronavirus crisis, with a full
hostel, 4 full move-on houses and almost 100 people temporarily accommodated
locally by Mid Sussex, Horsham and Crawley Councils. Whilst costs and workload have
increased it has been harder to raise funds and accept donations as a result of
the pandemic, a lack of community events and the damaged local economy. Any
donations towards their vital work through the ‘Hundred For The Homeless’
campaign will therefore be massively appreciated.

Description:
We have been working closely with the Cardinal Hume Centre for six years to support the great work that they do in helping young people who are homeless, refugees, asylum seekers and families who are sadly living below the poverty line at this trying time.

In order to raise awareness of what it means to be homeless and to help the students to have a great appreciation of all that we are privileged to have, the Upper Sixth students have been invited to take part in a sponsored ‘Sleep Out’. The students will be sleeping outside with a sleeping bag and cardboard as their home for the night, allowing them to have a small experience of how it feels to have very little, heighten awareness for those that are less fortunate and raise money to help people in need.

Any support that you can give will be greatly appreciated!
Title: Woldingham School's Sleep Out for Homelessness 25/02/22-26/02/22

Description: Serving the people of Birkenhead and the Wirral since 1892, the Mission looks to help men and women who are homeless, poor and needy, out of poverty. We provide hot food, clothing, toiletries, other basic essentials, along with much love, care and compassion. For many, the Mission is a place to come for friendship, food, support and advice. It’s a safe place that offers help. Without your support, we wouldn’t be able to play our part in this community.
Title: john paul's sleep out for the homeless,and less fortunate page

Description: On Monday 29th November we’ll be hosting a quiz night to raise funds for Wintercomfort for the homeless. Wintercomfort is a Cambridge based charity that offers support for rough sleepers and those under threat of eviction or sofa surfing. Cambridge has a serious problem with homeless and in the winter more than ever it’s important that we as a community step up to do whatever we can for the most vulnerable. So please be generous in giving to this cause; tackling these issues are at the heart of our politics and this is just one small way we can help. Everything raised will go to Wintercomfort to support them in their work. We are asking for a £3 minimum donation from all attendees - thank you!
Title: CULC's Charity Quiz

Description:
Welcome! Here at the Light Entertainment Society, we have three main aims: (1) be lightly entertaining, (2) perform for those who usually cannot access theatre e.g. those in care homes, (3) raise money for charity. As you might imagine, number 2 is not yet on the table BUT, we have produced a BRAND NEW piece of silly comedy in aid of our chosen charity for this term: Wintercomfort.

Wintercomfort is a charity that supports those who are homeless or vulnerably housed in Cambridge. Open daily, they provide meals, access to hygiene facilities, housing help, skills training, and counselling to safeguard and empower service users.

Listening is completely free, but if you are in a position to donate, any amount would be greatly appreciated!

Check out the radioplay below!

It was an offer she couldn’t refuse. When a struggling arts graduate Arizona is hired to steal a priceless urn from a world-famous museum, her eccentric boss puts together an unlikely team of thieves: a hyperactive teen, a film geek, and *checks notes* ...a polyamorous car salesman. Welp, one bad decision is not the end of the world... or is it?
With the international authorities on their heels, the crew must go on a quest over ranges and rivers, through sacred temples and airport security, to stop the apocalypse. But with time running out, can these archaeologically-inclined friends really solve the ancient mystery of the great bird-god Kevin? Or will the world as we know it be history…?
Title: CULES Michaelmas 2021 - ARIZONA JAMES AND THE RESTORERS OF THE STOLEN URN

Description: Homeless Oxfordshire is the largest provider of supported temporary accommodation for homeless adults in the county. Each night we accommodate 220 people. But we are more than bricks and mortar. Through 11 innovative projects, we provide the person-centred support people need to recover from homelessness for good.

Description: Julian House provides life changing support to over 1,000 vulnerable individuals across the South West, including those suffering from homelessness, women and children escaping domestic abuse and adults with learning difficulties. Alongside our emergency hostel, we also provide supported accommodation and training and education opportunities to help people gain confidence, re-build their lives and fulfil their potential.
Title: Helping the homeless

Description:
The Whitechapel Centre is a leading homeless and housing charity for the Liverpool region. We work with people who are sleeping rough, living in hostels or struggling to manage their accommodation. We are committed to help people to find and maintain a home and learn the life skills essential for independent living. 

In 2018-19 we worked with 4,323 people. Our projects reflect the diverse routes into & through homelessness. A variety of services, in different settings, compliment each other and ensure no one slips through the net of support.
Title: Supporting the homeless

Description:
Over 200,000 households in England are experiencing the worst forms of

without a home.

That's why I've chosen to Stay Awake with Crisis and I'm taking on 24 hours of fundraising to help end homelessness.

Title: Do it for the homeless

Description:
Over the past few days, news has leaked of a Cambridge student burning a £20 note in front of a homeless person. Slowly taking over national media (from broadsheets like the Independent to jokier media such as the ‘Ladbible’), every single one of us feels ashamed of the actions of this one individual. 

However the fundamental issue at hand is a far deeper one. Homelessness is far too prevalent in Cambridge, and it's time we ALL did something about it.

I ask you to donate a symbolic £20. £20 provides up to 20 meals for Jimmy's guests on any given day. £26 is the cost for a homeless person to have a bed, evening meal and breakfast, for each night. If we work together to bring about social change, then we can truly touch so many lives.

Let us respond to the problems in our society by working together. Let us show the world the kind and compassionate people we are. Let us get homelessness off our streets, making our society a better place for everyone. After all, isn't making a positive, meaningful, difference the reason why we all applied to Cambridge?

Title: Hope for the homeless!

Description:
Since moving to Bristol 5 and a half years ago, I've seen the levels of homelessness on our streets considerably increase. I have become friends with one man and a few weeks ago he got very unwell. After not seeing him for a few days, I found out that he was in hospital with pneumonia. Great - he's in the best place with round the clock care, but then what? He leaves hospital to find himself back on the streets with no warm bed, no regular access to food, exposed to the elements and his safety at constant risk. 

Homeless people in Bristol are dying at more than twice the national rate (with the average age of only 47) and it has hit a record high. Nobody should be dying unnoticed and unaccounted for and in this day and age there is no excuse for anyone dying without a safe place to call home. 

I am looking for donations of money for the Crisis charity ahead of Christmas and also for donations of warm clothing. I will be spending a night sleeping rough in 2020 with the organisation along with my wonderful friend Kitty and we will also be donating clothing to the Keep Bristol Warm project this December. 

If you do anything this festive season, please share this page and put your hand in your pocket to donate. Warm clothing donations can be brought to my place and we will take these down to the location for you.
Title: Homeless at Christmas

Description:
Harvest is a time for giving, a time for thanks and for recognising and sharing with those less fortunate. At Turning Tides, we have always been delighted to attend and give thanks at Harvest services. Last year we received food to the value of £25k from faith groups and schools which fed local homeless men and women through the following winter months.

Covid-19 has presented us with challenges and we had to carefully rethink our approach to Harvest. Transporting multiple items from homes, to schools and churches and then on to our projects inevitably increases the risk of infection.

Financial donations will enable us to purchase essential items according to need and, crucially, plan carefully to provide enough food for our clients for the full year ahead. The donations will also enable us to buy fresh produce which supports better health and immunity at this critical time.

Donations can be to the value of a £3 shopping bag, or a £30 shopping basket, or a £100 shopping trolley.

Title: My experience

Description: Drug and alcohol addiction is a disease that destroys the lives of many. A common side affect of addiction is homelessness. A study has found that 1 in 25 people in the UK are dependent on alcohol irrespective of income, education or race. At WBS we are supporting Changes UK to facilitate a conversation among business leaders about addiction and the workplace and to raise money for CEO Sleepout. No-one should be sleeping alone on the streets in freezing conditions. We are taking part in CEO Sleepout to help Changes UK in their mission to raise awareness about addiction and to help more people find recovery and a life of dignity and purpose. PS: At least two of our sleepout team are (very) nervous about the bracing cold of a December night on the streets of Birmingham!!
Title: Karen Barker's page

Description:
In April 2020 I signed up to  volunteer for The Dons Local Action Group (DLAG) 

It has honestly been one of the  most rewarding decisions I have ever made as well as  humbling to work alongside an amazing group of dedicated.volunteers,  see the generosity of donors and the fruits of our labour as we strive to support those in need 

DLAG provides food parcels, household goods, furniture and appliances to those in need in our communities. We also donate laptops through our Keep Kids Connected campaign for children who need access to online learning. 

We also work in partnership with a wide range of organisations throughout the boroughs of Kingston, Merton and Wandsworth. With their help, we are building a diverse and resilient community network to tackle the effects of food, furniture and digital poverty.

The work of one of our  partners is  supporting the homeless in our boroughs. Please help me raise money to continue this vital work .Thank you so much for your support!!!
Title: Dons Local Action Group - The Big Sleep Out 27th Nov at AFCW stadium

Description:
Today in London the number of rough sleepers has doubled over the past decade, with an average age of death at just 44 years old, with many from suicide. More than one in three people sleeping rough have deliberately been hit or kicked, and a third of women facing homelessness have experienced sexual violence.

You can make an incredible difference to the many rough sleepers who come to us for help  to people like Brian, a former guest at Webber Street. He said,

Three years ago, I was living absolutely outrageously on Londons Streets. I came to Webber Street because I needed somewhere to eat and freshen up. Today I have three meals, a full-time job, some balance in my life, I am part of a church family and the futures looking exciting. Every morning I am thankful that where I am is Gods work and that I am still being supported by London City Missionaries

Your gift today will help turn the lives of many in London.

Homelessness has effected me once in my life I was homeless for 2 years which was the worse experience of my life, luckily for me I had someone help me off the streets, not everyone is that lucky, what’s worse is the number of veterans out there suffering with homelessness so if you could take a moment and donate what ever you wish be it 50p , £1 what ever you chose it will go towards helping veteran on the streets of London.
Title: mrtangobravo763's Help 4 Homeless Veterans Gaming Marathon

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

I wanted to do something worthwhile and useful as well, ahead of my 60th birthday.  Being able to experience what homelessness means for the many rough sleepers in my city as well as the wider country, I was drawn to the Big Ibrox Sleep out as a way to do that in a safe environment but with nothing more than some warm clothes, a sleeping bag and sheet of cardboard to fully appreciate what rough sleepers have to put up with at the start of the winter period. Additionally, the lure of being able to do this in the safe environment of the iconic Ibrox Stadium, home of Rangers FC was too good an opportunity to pass up.  Raising money for a great cause and sleeping at the side of the pitch of my favourite football team.  Result..!!!

Maya's mum works in Social Services and in particular has worked extensively with the homeless for much of her working life.  Helping to raise money for the Rangers Charity Foundation and in turn, raising money for homelessness as the winter draws in.  Whilst highlighting awareness of homelessness, Maya is also helping to raise vital funds for Glasgow City Mission's Emergency Winter Project.  Her mum and me are so proud that she has volunteered to do this with great enthusiasm.

We would welcome kind donations from friends and family alike.

Title: Brian & Maya's page

Description:
The four of us will be running 1,5 and 10k dressed as Santa’s to raise money for Herts Young Homeless on December 4th 2021.

Every year around over 2,000 young people are referred to HYH for help, and in many cases it is clear that their homelessness could have been prevented. Being homeless is a disaster for anyone, but for a young person it can be a tragedy that sets a pattern for the rest of their life which is why it is our mission to prevent this in Hertfordshire.


Leaving home can sometimes seem an attractive or easier option than staying at home when you are young. But finding and keeping accommodation is fraught with difficulty, and all too easily teenagers can find themselves without a safe place to stay.

Young people currently leaving home are faced with a complex housing market where few housing options are available and significant changes to benefits have taken place. That’s why we are asking for your help this Christmas

Title: Chloe's Herts Young Homeless Family Santa Run page

Description:
I have been getting people to buy Change Please coffee for years, enabling people experiencing homelessness to get back into work and a home. Now it is my turn to step up.

Although my sleepout will be a walk (or sleep) in the park compared to the life of someone sleeping on our streets, I want to do something to support some of the other amazing homelessness organisations working towards ending homelessness.

Many of us take our homes and secure lives for granted but it doesn't take much for it all to fall apart. There are a myriad of reasons why someone may end up on the streets. Happily many of the pre-conceptions of people experiencing homelessness are becoming out-dated and a more understanding approach is coming to the fore. Although this is  a good step forwards we all need to do more, here are a few very sad statistics highlighting why:

  • Over 250,000 people in England are homeless and in temporary accommodation
  • Over 61% of adults in England living in temporary accommodation are women
  • Single parents make up 72% of all homeless families living in temporary accommodation, but only 24% of families
  • 1 in 23 black households become homeless or are at risk of becoming homeless, compared to 1 in 83 households from all other ethnicities
  • 24% of young homeless people in the UK are LGBT+
  • More than half (55%) of people who make a homeless application are aged between 16 and 34
    Source: Shelter, AKT, MHCLG

Thank you for sponsoring me and being a part of the movement to support some of our societies most vulnerable people. 

You are awesome!

Jules
x
Title: Sleeping out for people experiencing homelessness.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I love a good charitable cause and with the rise of young adults becoming homeless in a first world country now is the time to help put a stop to this. I will be putting myself out there - so here I am committing myself to sleep rough on 19th November (yes in the cold come rain or shine) in support of Herts Young Homeless. No tent, no heater - just sleeping bags, cardboard and hot drinks. 

Herts Young Homeless support vulnerable young people who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, working with them to achieve the best possible outcomes.

What they say - "Our focus is on preventing homelessness - from education in schools and family mediation through to supporting 16-24 year olds in their first homes or caring for adults of all ages who have mental health issues and housing needs.

Our services empower young people to be able to deal with the difficult situations in their lives, giving them the ability and confidence to 'do it themselves' and ultimately find stability."

Please support me and give to this amazing cause.

Description:
Every Christmas, thousands of people turn to The Salvation Army for help. In over 650 communities up and down the UK, hundreds of volunteers will be rolling up their sleeves and helping the most vulnerable in society get through what is already a difficult time of year.  

This year, we are pleased to be supporting such a wonderful cause that will assist the 280,000 people who are left homeless in the UK. We understand this has been a difficult year for everyone, so anything you can do to help would be appreciated to no end. Description:
Last year after a trip to London, Thomas was very moved by the amount of homeless people he saw and wanted to raise money to help them. Title: Sponsor Thomas to sleep on his floor on Easter Friday

Description:
I have chosen to support the Salvation Army because I believe in the world wide vision that together everybody achieves more, we can provide so much of our time & money to dedicate our support to such a brilliant on-going cause to reach out to those out in the world whom may not have a voice to get heard and protest their needs to survive.

Everybody has the ability to be an uncover hero, but we can't do this alone, we all need each other to come together and help save our communities.

"If we don't help each other and keep living in ignorance , nobody will get anywhere. The issue will still be there." Never judge a book by it's cover,

If we don't pull together more people will grow hungrier barely keeping alive like some already, we've all got something to offer doing what we can to see another day prosper, money goes to money is why the homeless stay poorer.

If we could all just pull together we could change our society for the better.

I politely ask anybody could kindly donate what ever they can to this great cause, you'll all be benefiting so many broken lives with just one click.

Title: Kay's Raising Awareness for Homelessness Worldwide

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The homeless of the UK and more so in our city of Birmingham are in need of our kindness. They were once like you and me, with family, home and stability but for whatever reason life took an unexpected turn and today they are left homeless on the street whilst we are still within the comforts of our home and in the company of our family. 

I have pledged to raise £1000 for the As-Suffa Homeless Outreach programme that does a tremendous job in not only providing the homeless with much needed nutritious food but also lending an attentive ear, easing their hardship and respecting them like every human being ought to be. 

Winter has gone and they have survived some harsh outdoor conditions but that doesn't mean we stop giving. So I kindly ask that you donate whatever you can big or small whether it is sadaqa or lillah. 


Abu Huraira reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, “Charity does not decrease wealth. - Sahih Muslim

Title: Rubana's As-Suffa Homeless Outreach

Description: We will be walking round Draycote Water to raise money for our new community partner Emmaus. We know that overcoming homelessness often means more than a roof over your head. That’s why Emmaus supports people to work their way out of homelessness, providing meaningful work as well as a stable home for as long as someone needs it.
Title: Nicola’s page

Description:
Having been struck by COVID-19, I spent most of March in bed recovering. While ending up in hospital twice during my recovery, I experienced the incredible work the NHS were doing to help battle COVID, and launched a campaign to donate 100 pizzas to the NHS during the months of April and May as my way to give back to them.

As part of my recovery I started walking, and have consequently decided to challenge myself to walk 500km to help raise some money for another great cause. The Fine & Country Foundation are dedicated to battling the causes of homelessness and aiding those who are affected by it. Homelessness is a cause close to my heart, and in our town is very prevalent.

It’s up to all of us to do something in one way, shape or form. I have set a target to raise £1000, and I'm asking you all to sponsor me so that together we can raise some money for this incredible cause.
Title: Sanjay's 504km Walk for the Homeless

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Alex's and my JustGiving page.

This pandemic has shown us all the importance of having a
home you feel safe in. The 'Everybody In' campaign has seen many homeless people given shelter, however there has been a recent increase in the number of people rough sleeping for the first time. Longer term solutions need to be found. Crisis works year round directly with homeless people as well as through research and campaigns .

Litter has a devastating impact on our wildlife. We’ve all seen pictures of wildlife entangled in rope, or plastic rings and more recently elastic from face masks, plus birds and animals mistake small objects for food.
And that is before we think about the plastic in our seas slowly degrading but never going away. 

Alex and I have been litter picking regularly during lockdown and have been struck by the sheer weight of rubbish just in our local streets (when we are lugging it home!) and also how quickly it builds up.

So we are trying to raise money for Crisis while also helping the planet! Please support us if you can..

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Title: Litter picking for Homelessness

Description: Often overlooked aspect of homelessness, their pets are their only family they have beside them day in day out. Victims of the UK homelessness epidemic often have scant support, except for, in a growing number of cases, the companionship of their pets.Many have had their pets since before losing their homes, which makes their bond even more profound, such that their pet's well-being is a life-shaping priority. Our volunteer vets and vet nurses provide accessible fundamental veterinary care. We vaccinate, microchip, treat for fleas and worms, prescribe pain relief, help fight infections, perform surgeries and sometimes just sit and listen. Please give where and if you can xx
Title: Lisa's Homeless furr babies 🐾

Description:
Every year St. Basils, a young peoples charity in the Midlands, run a Hike for Homeless with this year's edition on Saturday 24 July.  

This charity is close to our hearts as my mother, Judy, has worked for them for a number of years and so we get to hear first-hand about the great work they do on a range of issues for young people.

We're doing this year's walk as a family which means that, while the 6-mile trek is not too bad for me, for mom and dad (who turns 69 the day before!) the ups and downs of the Warwickshire hills in the summer heat will be a real challenge and definitely deserving of some donations!

Conscious of the many worthy asks for fundraising, I'm going for volume not value here and so am asking people to donate just £2 (YES JUST TWO QUID) to the cause (of course, go nuts if you want to donate more!) so please be generous with the few minutes it takes to click through and together we can hopefully raise something meaningful for a great charity.

Thank you.

Joel
Title: Joel's Hike For Homeless 2021 page

Description:
We should all have a place to call home. Across the UK, thousands of people will be without a home this Christmas. 

I will be volunteering with Crisis this Christmas. Social distancing means well be doing things differently, but well be looking after as many people as we possibly can. And the spirit of a Crisis Christmas will be exactly the same. 

We will treat people with care and respect  giving them that warm Crisis welcome, so they get their dignity back and feel ready to take on life again.

Could you sponsor me and give the gift of a Crisis Christmas?

Title: Football Supporting the Homeless

Description:
I’ve decided to grow a beard to raise money for homelessness
charity St Mungos. 

While we’re all trying to come to terms with the Covid-19 pandemic, and the impacts on our lives, loved ones, our jobs and our businesses, homeless people are still on the streets facing the same struggles they do normally.

Except now, there are much fewer people around to give them
the spare change they need to find a hostel or to buy them food. Some support organisations are having to scale back their activity because of social distancing. And, arguably, the government may be even less inclined to find the additional support for homeless people over the coming months.

If we think being isolated in our warm and comfortable homes
is difficult, I would imagine it’s nothing like being isolated living on the
streets.

I want to do something to help, and you can too.

I’m 38 years old and I’ve never grown a beard. I’ve never really had a strong urge to. When my stubble gets to a certain length it gets
scratchy and annoying. I certainly don’t like the idea food being caught in my beard, and I don’t have a clue about beard care. Plus, I’m used to being able to see my chin.

I’m going to put up with all these (hopefully minor) inconveniences
to raise sponsorship money to grow a beard for homelessness. While I’m a hermit in isolation, I may as well have a hermit’s beard.

Please support me.

Title: Bobby's Sponsored homeless for a night

Description:
On the 11th of August myself, Rhodri and Pei will be undertaking a 24 hour mixing marathon to raise money for the fantastic charity, Crisis.

The three of us will be DJing continuously for 24 hours in the hope to raise some awareness and money in order to help bring homelessness to an end.

Homelessness in the UK, and around the world, is a rising avoidable and preventable tragedy. It is a problem that can be fixed, but is also a problem which has chosen to be ignored by many. Thousands of people are pushed into this unsettling existence each year, and although steps are being taken to tackle the problem of rough sleeping, there is still much work to be done.

By helping various charities and with the work of some fantastic services around the country, the damaging limbo of homelessness can be defeated. Please help and show support by donating through our 'JustGiving' page, we appreciate any and all contributions - thank you very much!

Tune in on the 11th of August from 9AM onwards as we prepare for the longest back2back2back session North Wales has ever seen! We will be streaming live from various social media platforms including YouTube, Facebook and Instagram for you all to watch and listen.

Let’s bring an end to homelessness!

-

Mis nesaf mi fydda'i, Rhodri a Pei yn ymgymryd â sialens heriog - DJ'io am 24 awr cyfan i godi arian ar gyfer yr elusen anhygoel, 'Crisis'.

Bydd y tri ohonom yn DJ'io yn barhaus am 24 awr gyda'r gobaith i godi ymwybyddiaeth ac arian er mwyn helpu i ddod â digartrefedd i ben.

Mae digartrefedd yn y Ddeurnas Unedig, ac o gwmpas y byd, yn broblem fedra ni eu hosgoi yn gyfan gwbwl. Mae miloedd o bobl y flwyddyn yn troi'n ddigartref heb ddewis, ac er bod camau'n cael eu gymeryd i fynd i'r afael gyda'r phroblem o gysgu'n arw ar y stryd, mae llawer o waith i'w wneud o hyd.

Drwy helpu elusennau a gyda gwaith gwasanaethau gwych ledled y wlad, gallwn drechu'r trasiedi hon rwan. Helpwch a dangoswch gefnogaeth drwy gyfrannu ar ein tudalen 'JustGiving', rydym yn gwerthfawrogi unrhyw fath o gyfraniadau, bach neu mawr - diolch o galon!

Ymunwch gyda ni ar yr 11eg o Awst o 9AM ymlaen wrth i ni baratoi ar gyfer y sesiwn b2b2b hiraf mae Gogledd Cymru erioed 'di weld!! Byddwn yn streamio'n fyw o wahanol lwyfannau cyfryngau cymdeithasol gan gynnwys YouTube, Facebook ac Instagram i chi i gyd wylio a gwrando.

Helpwch i ni ddod a ddigartrefedd i ben!

Title: Marathon Mix For Homelessness

Description:
Each night The Y provides 120 beds to young people who have no safe place to call home.  A young person who has suffered trauma, family breakdown or abuse will take many little steps before they are ready to leave The Y with confidence to set up a home of their own.

£10 buys a welcome pack for someone with no belongings.
£80 could buy interview clothes and shoes
£275 could pay for a month of specialist support for a young person who has suffered abuse

Any amount YOU can give will help a young person leave homelessness behind for GOOD.
Title: Pattern Gang For Eliminating Youth Homelessness
georgia's Help the homeless for the new year

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Description:
Over 83,000 young people are experiencing homelessness right now.

Violence, abuse, neglect and problems with mental health - young people often become homeless because it's safer to leave home than to stay. 

End Youth Homelessness (EYH) is a coalition of charities that provide safe and stable places for over 26,000 young people to live across the UK. 

I'm fundraising to End Youth Homelessness.

Title: Stephanie 's Warming up the Homeless

Description:
Its hard to protect yourself from the coronavirus outbreak when youre homeless. People who are sleeping rough are more likely to suffer from respiratory conditions. They cant wash their hands. And if someone is sleeping rough or in a crowded night shelter, its impossible to self-isolate.I'm raising vital funds to support Crisis in their work to help homeless people. 

Anyone can be homeless. I should know this as a few wrong decisions nearly got  me closer to that feeling in the past. 

There's only one thing that's certain in these uncertain times. Its a time to pull together and help each other. I would be grateful, if you could contribute in my fundraising task. Under the current conditions, what I can offer in return of your kind donation is limited. However, when we meet, I promise to buy you your favourite drink, chocolate or offer some home-made spices for your cooking. 

Go on then, let's help each other! We are in this together!

Title: Justine's End youth homelessness

Description:
I will be sleeping out on my own in my tent for 7 days, that’s a whole week from 28 November until 4 December when it will be dark, cold, wet and windy. Why? To raise funds for homeless people, and I’m aiming for at least £100 per night. 

With Christmas approaching, most of us are hoping to see our family,  loved ones and friends. Imagine being on the street during a pandemic - feeling bleak, cold, hungry and vulnerable. Please give, even if it's only the cost of a cup of coffee, but more if you can afford it. £3 will pay for a meal, and £30 will give someone a Christmas with a warm bed, food, friendship and care.

The money will go to Julian House in Bristol who provide life changing support to over 1,400 vulnerable individuals per year across the South West, including those suffering from homelessness, women and children escaping domestic abuse and adults with learning difficulties. Alongside the emergency hostel, they also provide supported accommodation and training and education opportunities to help people gain confidence, re-build their lives and fulfill their potential.

If you, like me, feel fortunate to have a roof over your head, regular meals, and people you love, please do consider giving generously.
Thank you very much.

Title: S's Help the Homeless - be an Angel

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My goal is to offer basic necessities to the homeless living on the streets of London, ensuring that people in need can have their basic needs met.

The Lovecarepackages will be assembled and filled with daily needs that we sometimes take for granted, containing everything from water to deodorant and things in between. As a special touch, all packages will include a handwritten personal note of encouragement.

"But first you must change your environment..."

My aim is to build and deliver 50 care packages for the homeless living in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets. This is something that is happening right on my doorstep and I am faced with on a daily basis, so I decided that it was time for me to give back and do my little bit to help those in my community. 

I initially planned on doing this alone, until someone told me that the more I spread the word, the more help I get and with help, the more I will be able to do, as it takes more than one person to make a change.

Thank you in advance for helping me make a difference.

Description:
NEED DONATIONS!!!!!!!!!

On Saturday 8th July me and Kian Rawcliffe are doing a 24 hour homeless challenge!

This means we're not allowed our phone, we're only allowed a sleeping bag each,the clothes we're in and some cardboard for shelter!

During the 24 hours we are going to be allowed  4, 10 minutes toilet breaks and are going to do challenges and dares to each other.

This money is going to a really good cause so littlest of money does count!
Title: Luke, Kian and George's 24hr homeless challenge

Description:
Hi All

So this time last month a friend of mine who also runs his own business Decky Valeting Services came to me and asked if I could help him with one thing which is close to his heart. Helping Homeless for Christmas holidays!

We have had numerous meetings with Welcome Organization and we have put plans together of what our goals are to help contribute towards finding funds, gifts, and much more to help our Homeless.

We will put a poster up tomorrow of what we need to gather up along with details of our fundraiser we are having at McCartans The Fort Bar on Friday 8th December. Decky has also agreed to donate all takings made on his valeting business from now until Christmas to help towards our goal.

Any help appreciated and Welcomed. If you have any ideas or gifts please pm me or Decky.

Just giving page is now live if anyone wants to donate towards our goal!
#helpingourhomeless
#wepulltogether
#christmas2017

Title: Carla's Helping the Homeless at Christmas

Description:
I am raising money for 'Real Change Wigan & Leigh' to helps end and prevent homelessness for people in Wigan and Leigh.

We can all see the impact homelessness is having in Wigan and Leigh. Whether rough sleeping, begging or sofa surfing, people who are homeless have poorer health, are more vulnerable to violence or abuse, and can often struggle to keep a job or stay in touch with their family. 

Real Change Wigan & Leigh is a partnership of charities and groups working to end homelessness alongside people with direct experience. 

Too often, the barrier is people's lack of access to the simple things we might all take for granted: money for a rent deposit, clothes for a job interview, or even a bus ticket to get to their new accommodation. 'Real Change Wigan and Leigh' need your help to provide practical items like these. 

Donate now to help end homelessness in Wigan & Leigh.

Find out more at www.realchangewiganandleigh.co.uk
#RealChangeWL
Title: Real Change Wigan and Leigh

Title: Adam's Help The Homeless this Winter

Description:
Since I left London in 2012, homelessness has increased by almost 170%. There is a visible homeless crisis in San Francisco, London and the World with people being forced to sleep on the streets.

Homelessness can happen very quickly and to anyone. Life changes quickly and recovery is tough. Specialist support, shelter and campaigning are only possible with the support of people like you. Together we can help this important cause to rebuild lives going forward. 

I know what it is like to have to leave a country you call home (twice) but I am privileged to have the support, skills and resources to start again. Many don't. I am fundraising for the Connections as they support people to recover from the trauma of street homelessness. 

Please help by donating what you can to help me meet my £2000 goal by World Homeless Day on October 10. Let's raise awareness and funds to support this marginalised population. 

80% of people have reported a mental health issue. 

The average age expectancy of someone living on the streets is 47.

In response I am:

  • Volunteering to help London's homeless 
  • Offering free fitness classes to boost mental health and raise awareness of rough sleeping with my community
  • Going sober for October to raise awareness of alcohol and drug dependency amongst those who are homeless

Homelessness is still a devastating issue in our society, and more resources are needed to end this epidemic.

Please donate as generously as you feel. It really goes a long way. And remember, never take your home for granted.
Title: Please support those who are homeless

Description:
We see homeless people every time we leave the house, we all do!

My sister and I always give money or buy them food but this one time we gave a lovely a man a meal deal and he sobbed, he was so grateful for a sandwich and a drink. He couldn’t thank us enough, we couldn’t imagine not knowing when our next meal would be, where we will sleep, if we are safe, what if it rains? where can you go if your wet and cold, if you’re poorly?

We all take what we have for granted to so we wanted to give something back!

Any money we raise will go to the Shelter homeless charity and any donations we receive will go to a local homeless shelter!

We are looking for donations of bedding, Clothing, non perishable food and drink items and hygiene items!

Thankyou ❤️
Title: Zoe & Tara Are Sleeping On The Streets For The Homeless

Description:
My dear friends and supports I have made it to the finalist for the Pure UK International for 2020 and my purpose is to help support the communities and charities I am very passionate about.

Appreciate Gratitude and not to take anything for granted. I am going to be sharing an evening and celebrating Diwali on the streets of London with the homeless

My late father left his legacy in Kisumu Kenya feeding the street children and tackling homelessness, child poverty, elderly abandoned people through a charity that he set up.🇰🇪🦋

Till today my brother and his family continue to dedicate their time and support to running this charity.❤️🙏

This has inspired me to do something similar here and that is why I have taken on this challenge. 🇰🇪♥️👨‍👨‍👧‍👦🥫🥪

On the 26th October I will be offering some homeless people on the streets of London a home cooked meal, clothing to keep them warm and I have approached a few sponsors and as well as raising money for my First chosen charity:

The Salvation Army United Kingdom with the Republic of Ireland

Title: Henry, Oscar & Finn's Homeless Camp Out

Description:
Tis the season for giving; alongside a collection of items to hand out to the homeless we are raising money for Barnabus.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKcnGbpvWE0&feature=youtu.be

Barnabus are a frontline Christian Homeless Charity in
Manchester; providing a lifeline to rough sleepers and people with lived
experience of homelessness for over 25 years. Last
year we supported 2,496 individual people; 66% of those were rough sleeping
in our City.

Barnabus provide practical help and support including food, clothing, showers
and healthcare. We also offer creative and inspiring skill focused activities
to help increase confidence, skills, rehabilitation and employability. Our
support and resettlement team help those in need move on from the streets and
away from emergency accommodation into their own tenancies and back into
independent living.

Barnabus
are passionate about ending homelessness in our City. We hope you will support
our work and be part of the solution to bring transforming change?

https://www.barnabus-manchester.org.uk/

facebook  @barnabusmanchester  / twitter & instagram @BarnabusMcr

﻿﻿﻿This is one of many fundraisers Kier FSSC Manchester have done throughout the past year, raising over £6000 for various charities; so for anyone who has donated to a fundraiser previously thank you!

Title: Raising money for the homeless

Description:
We have a test pressing of our new vinyl album to giveaway. All we're asking is for a small donation to Shelter for your chance to win.

The latest figures showed that 4,751 people slept rough across England on any given night in 2017 - a 15% increase compared to the previous year, and more than double the amount in 2010.

Temperatures this winter look set to be the lowest in 50 years. Let's see if we can raise a little bit of money to help those forced to sleep on the streets.

Please donate as little or as much as you can afford and we'll pick one person at random to win the LP.

Title: Help The Homeless This Christmas

Description:
Every year since 2010, more people have found themselves sleeping on our streets. StreetLink exists to help connect people sleeping rough to local support services by enabling members of the public to send an alert when they see someone sleeping out.

Since we launched, over 150,000 alerts have been sent about people sleeping rough and thousands of people have been offered the support they need to escape rough sleeping.

Title: Help the homeless fundraiser

Description:
On Friday 12th April, at the ungodly hour of 7am, I'll be donning my goggles at Bradford on Avon pool to complete a 2.5km (100 lengths) swim in aid of St Mungo's. 

For nearly 50 years, St Mungo’s has been at the forefront of efforts to tackle homelessness. Each night their 17 outreach teams go out to help people sleeping rough to move away from the streets, and they provide a bed and support to over 2,800 people. They work to prevent homelessness and support people at every step of their recovery from homelessness.

Title: Helping the Homeless in Winter

Description:
Simon on the Street exists to provide support to those people in our community, who are often excluded from, or who refuse the intervention of other services, with a view to empower them to change their lives.

Adopting a usually long term approach, we achieve this by providing our service users support directly on the street through outreach. Our support is unconditional, all times of day and night. We provide motivation towards accessing a wide range of services to help improve the health of our service users and life choices they make.
Title: Marketing Optimist Helping Yorkshires Homeless

Description:
Helping the homeless, especially at Christmas is something I've wanted to do for years and after reading a particularly heartbreaking story I've decided to finally do something about it. I originally wanted to make a lot of care packages to hand out but after speaking to Glasgow City Mission it appears the best option is to give them funding directly to help provide food and shelter to homeless people in Glasgow. We're all so fortunate to wake up in our warm homes on Christmas morning surrounded by family, food and gifts but not everyone is as fortunate. No one should spend Christmas alone on the streets so if everyone could donate a little and share I'd really appreciate it. Every penny helps. Your donations go directly to Glasgow City Mission and can make a huge difference to a lot of people.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Title: Harry's Hairless for homeless homies

Description:
Hello! Thank you for taking the time to visit our page!

We are a group of young currently on the NCS Programme run by Inspire Suffolk. The NCS Programme is to help young people ages 16-17 to complete a social action project.

We've chosen for our social action project to support the homeless and less fortunate population in the Ipswich area. We plan to achieve this by working with Ipswich Outreach who are in need of additional supplies to give to people in need and the Ipswich Food Bank. We kindly ask for your help by donating a small amount. The money raised will contribute towards two different causes:

1. Ipswich Outreach - We will prepare food parcels because their traditional way of feeding the homeless via soup kitchen is not as efficient due to COVID. So they are in need for wrapped foods such as bottled water, biscuits, crisps, cereal bars. We've been given a target to make 30 parcels. 

2. Excess funds will go towards buying essential products for the food bank because they tend to get an enormous amount of donations which they don't need. This allows us to provide them with some of the specific things they need.

Description: Last year over 110,000 young people, aged between 16-25 years in the UK were homeless or are at risk of homelessness. Some facing serious danger on the streets. Without the right help at the right time, this downward spiral lasts through adulthood. But there’s still hope. With the right opportunities and support, homeless young people can turn their lives around and build successful futures, which, along with End Youth Homelessness, we're challenging you to SLEEP OUT (or sleep in) to raise awareness and vital funds to help vulnerable young people find a safe, secure place to call home. Never before have small, individual actions been so powerful. Let’s join forces to end youth homelessness and give young people a brighter future. COME TOGETHER ACT TOGETHER Sign up to take part

Description:

Violence, abuse, neglect and problems with mental health - young people often become homeless because it's safer to leave home than to stay. 

End Youth Homelessness (EYH) is a coalition of charities that provide safe and stable places for over 30,000 young people to live across the UK. 

I'm fundraising to End Youth Homelessness.
Title: TBS coventry, End youth Homelessness

Description:
Hatsagainst homelessness

Mystery Hat

I am making mystery handmade knitted hats, with £5 from each hat being donated to the Salvation Army via JustGiving.They can be purchased from the link below:

https://www.etsy.com/uk/listing/959812323/hats-against-homelessnessmystery?ref=shop_home_active_1&frs=1

I am currently knitting as many hats as possible, ready to donate to the Salvation Amy to be donated to homeless people in my local area (Suffolk). To go one step further I thought I would offer hats on my Etsy that can be purchase at a cost of £10, £5 of which I will donate directly to the Salvation Army to help them continue the fantastic work they do. The other £5 will cover my materials, listing and selling fees and delivery charges.

I have set up a JustGiving page, where I will be donating £5 every sale, with a running total of hats sold at each donation point.

Please like, share and comment to spread the word!

You can read more about the great work the Salvation Army do here:

https://www.salvationarmy.org.uk/

Twenty four hours a day, every day of the year. The Salvation Army provide care and support to people in need. In fact its what we've done for over 150 years. It is what we continue to do today and its what we will go on doing whenever and wherever there is injustice and pain in the world.We help people affected by disasters or financial troubles. We help people who are experiencing homelessness or escaping violence We help people trapped in addiction or battling mental illness We help anyone feeling hopeless.We are a community- a movement of people fighting injustice. Our donors and supporters- people like you- are as much a part of The Salvation Army as those working in our recovery centres or regional communities. Together we offer unconditional love and support, without discrimination. The Salvation Army is committed to delivering innovative and progressive services that empower people beyond their circumstances.

Title: Homeless 4 a Night 2021

Description:
For over 50 years, St Mungo’s has been at the forefront of efforts to tackle homelessness. Each night their 17 outreach teams go out to help people sleeping rough to move away from the streets, and they provide a bed and support to over 3,150 people. They work to prevent homelessness and support people at every step of their recovery from homelessness.

In 2021, the fact that we still have so many people without a home makes me sick. Therefore, it is important that we help to support the charities battling homelessness where we can. This is why we have decided that on the 4th July, we will head to Basildon Sports and Leisure Club to raise as much money as we can in aid of St Mungo’s in their ongoing battle against homelessness.

Description:
As part of Claudia's Silver Duke of Edinburgh requirements, she has chosen long distance walking as part of the challenge. When Greg Mangham who runs Only a Pavement Away (OAPA) - a charity Claudia has personally supported for the last two years, suggested the idea of hiking up Snowdonia to raise funds for OAPA, she knew immediately this would be the perfect finale for her training - now to July 2022.

But not one to miss out, I - her dad - am doing it with her.

We hope you can support her and the amazing charity that is Only A Pavement Away, which works tirelessly to keep the homeless off the streets and get them into work within the hospitality sector.

Any size donation will be hugely appreciated, thank you!

Love
Claudia and Paul
Title: Claudia's DofE Silver with OAPA

Description:
Our NCS group is made up of 14 young people on a 4 week long program, for the last two weeks of our program we have to 'Make a Change'. For this we all came to the conclusion that Caring in Bristol, a charity to help the homeless, was the charity we wanted to support.

One member of our team, Diana, said:

' I think we all take what we have for granted and some people have lost that luxury for different reasons. We are all part of one society so we should help those who need it, by doing this we are helping people live a better life.'

Janet is also passionate about this cause. She said:

"It's a very difficult position. Not only is it miserable to see but it tarnishes the ethos of Bristol as a city. Bristol represents everyone who lives in it, for visitors and outsiders the image of Bristol will not be the best. Also, providing aid for homeless people will promote kind behaviour."

 We will be partaking in various fundraising activities, such as waxing legs, coffee mornings and cake sales. We also hope to spend one night sleeping on the streets of Bristol at the end of August, both to raise awareness and money.

If we can reach our goal of £1,000 it will enable fifteen homeless people to sleep in a safe and secure homeless shelter in Bristol for an entire week! We would greatly appreciate any money that you could donate as this is a cause we feel very strongly about and want to support. 

Thank you,

NCS Team 4

Title: Mustafa's London 2 Brighton Bike Ride for the Homeless 17/09/17

Description:
St Mungo's is enabling people who are homeless to enjoy lunch at Euston station on Christmas Day. Up to 200 guests will enjoy a three course meal, entertainment and Christmas gifts.

The station concourse will be filled with decorations, and tables will be laid so that the guests, who will include St Mungo's clients from Camden and nearby areas, can enjoy a full Christmas dinner and some company.

Our Community and Events Manager, Beth Norden, says 'Many people become homeless because of relationship breakdowns so Christmas can be a lonely time for our residents'

We want to make this experience as enjoyable and memorable as possible for our guests. We are asking for donations to help cover some costs for the day - including transportation costs to bring guests to the station.

Any additional funds will be donated to St Mungo's services, which provide a bed and support to more than 2,700  people a night.

Thank you for your support.
Title: Euston Christmas Day lunch for homeless people

Description:
If you've landed here, you've probably clicked on the QR code on the artwork shown on this page. Called "BOX K50 (no second night out)", it's a portrait on canvas, framed in an old Amazon box, of a homeless guy I saw sleeping in a shaft of sunlight under some scaffolding in central London. He was so beautiful, his situation so ugly.

The portrait seems to move people, but would someone buy it to put on their wall? I've incorporated a QR code in the pre-printed box on the Amazon packaging to link to this page, so that when the portrait's exhibited, people can donate to Crisis if the artwork resonates with them. And if the portrait sells, I'll donate the proceeds to Crisis too.

I am hoping to find other ways to help the homeless if anyone has any other ideas. I can't imagine being sat out in this weather with no one to help me, waiting on some form of human kindness.

We are lucky to have the warmth and luxury to put the heater on when ever we want and to have warm clothing to wear when we go out, but the homeless people don’t! 

Recently a death was caused due to the cold and surely we don't want anymore deaths due to the same reason so please donate as much or as little as you can and help me raise money for the homeless so they can have warmth and food through the winter.


£30 = provide 3 winter blankets


£50 = provide 1 family with food for a month


£100 = food + clothing + blankets for 1 month


£150 = fuel for heating + food + blankets + clothing for 1 month


£300 – 500 = life saving emergency winter shelter


If we do not act now, people will die

Title: Lauren's End youth homelessness

Description:
What do you get when you combine a national lockdown, an old staircase and a need to increase your fitness level?

A challenge to 'climb' the 21 tallest buildings in the world over the next 21 days while raising funds for those who have nowhere to rest their heads right now, inspired by Kunal Bedarkar's initiative in Mumbai.

This amounts to going up and down over 4000 flights of stairs – the Health app on my phone would implode from shock if it could (or at least scoff loudly). If you're curious, you can find the tallest 21 buildings here.

In the process, I’d love your support to help raise funds for some of the people who have been hit particularly hard by the current situation (see the details below).

To make things more fun, as a tutor, I’m asking some of my students to find ways to make the process more challenging for me each time we hit a £100 mark while fundraising. Let’s face it, what brings a student more delight than an opportunity to make their teacher uncomfortable?  :) 

Anything you can contribute, no matter how small, would be greatly appreciated. I'd also be really grateful if you could share this campaign with others.

Funds will go to St. Mungo’s. 

Homelessness and St. Mungo’s

While many of us do our part to combat the current crisis by staying at home, over 300,000 people in the UK have no home to speak of. Thousands of others are suddenly at risk of losing theirs.

Akuba Quansah, from Ealing, tells the story of Norma, who found herself seeking safety in Heathrow Airport and then on a bench before visiting a local homeless shelter in search of food. Norma is unable to self-isolate and struggles to engage with authorities because of mental health issues. As Akuba puts it, there are many, many others like Norma.

St. Mungo’s is charity that is working hard to accommodate those who are sleeping rough. The charity’s outreach teams work round the clock to help ensure that as many homeless people as possible isolate safely, have access to food and social support. Can you imagine going through this crisis with the feeling that you have absolutely no one to turn to?

In the words of Rutger Bregman, Dutch historian and author of Utopia for Realists, “Every euro invested in fighting and preventing homelessness in the Netherlands enjoys double or triple returns in savings on social services, police, and court costs. […] Relief for the homeless, in short, is a win-win-win-win policy."

By enacting this vital policy, we help another human being feel a little less alone.

Description:
Julian House needs your help to rebuild lives this year. 

The last year has made many of us feel vulnerable, but for the people we support this is nothing new. 

Even before COVID-19 arrived most of the people in our care were vulnerable and often isolated from mainstream society. The pandemic made their situation even more stressful and, in many cases, riskier. This was especially true for those without a home, experiencing domestic abuse, struggling with addiction and/or mental health issues. 

The pandemic has also had a devastating effect on Julian Houses voluntary income at a time when the demand for our services has increased. With fundraising events being cancelled and our charity shops and bike workshops having to close temporarily, our voluntary income as taken a significant blow. Vital voluntary income needed to fund our life-saving services. 

Your support can help rebuild more lives. Please donate today

Title: Suzanne's End Youth Homelessness

Description:
Hi

Thank you for visiting my fundraising page.

﻿I am participating in the Bradford Sleep Out event on Thursday, 9th November 2017 in aid of End Youth Homelessness.

Each year in the UK, there are 83,000 homeless young people, which is something that no young person should ever experience. End Youth Homelessness (EYH) is a collation of charities that work directly with 29,000 young people who are amongst the most deprived in the UK and help them get their lives back on track.

No family, no job, no food, no place to go! What do you say to that? Having somewhere safe and stable to live is something many of us take for granted but homelessness can really happen to anyone.

So, let's run the WTOH (What's The Opportunity Here) question. Let's hunt for something good ... like what's the nicest thing you could do for someone with no place to go? Show care, give help, do a random act of kindness ... to bring a smile on their face. For me, personally, this is an opportunity to spread awareness of the EYH movement and to give back to the community. It is also an opportunity to make a difference, however small, help those in need, change someone's life, contribute towards providing support to young people into education, into work, into a home. In a nutshell, it is a great opportunity to do something good.

I would really appreciate it if you would sponsor me. I am aiming to raise £250, so please help me out!

100% of your funds go straight to EYH and Gift Aid, so an extra 25% of your contribution, is added automatically, at no cost to you.

Thank you so much for your support.

﻿

Title: Scott's close shave for the homeless

Description:
A MASSIVE THANKYOU!

I am thrilled to confirm that on the evening of December 25th Wander Woman officially walked the wall!

While most people were tucking into turkey and roast potatoes this festive season, I was dressed as 'Wander Woman' walking 100 miles from one side of England to the other to raise awareness and money for youth homeless chartiy Centrepoint.

I started with a visit to Centrepoint's northernmost office and drop-in centre in Sunderland on the shortest day (and longest night) and walked up to Newcastle on 22nd, then across England, following Hadrian's Wall, ending in Cumbria at Bowness-on-Solway late in the evening on Christmas Day.

I'm know for choosing to sleep in 'wild' locations as an adventurer, but this was my toughest challenge yet. That's because you can't wild camp on the wall - it's illegal, so I had to walk steadily through the night, in cold and dark conditions, by myself, with only short stops to 'rest' - all the while in costume.

It meant I missed out on on the festivities with my friends and family, but I think it was worth it to highlight the plight of many thousands of young homeless people who also have to keep moving through the night, unable to sleep anywhere legally and safely.

I was lucky enough to have an end date to my challenge, but there are so many who don't. Their walk must seem endless, and such it would be were it not for Centrepoint who work tirelessly to not only house them but also support them to get any education, life skills and the services of mental health professionals that they might need.

Last year over 100,000 young people approached their local council for help with homelessness, meaning that every mile I walked represented over 1,000 young people who would love to have had a place to call home surrounded by loved ones this Christmas.

Every £1 you donate and every step I took, brings us closer to ending homelessness for good. Please, please donate and help get these youngsters off the streets.

Thank you so much for your kindness.

WE DID IT!!!

Title: Rachel's Helping the homeless at Christmas

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Zulema and Harriet's JustGiving page.

A little about who these girls are: both are nine years old and they have been the best of friends since they first met in P1. They were both impacted recently when they noticed homeless people on the streets in Belfast. Zulema regretted not donating her Christmas money at the time and Harriet couldn't stop thinking about one woman and her dog who were living on the street. 

One late morning after a sleepover, they ran into the kitchen with a list of eighteen ways that they wanted to raise money for the homeless. It turns out discussing what they could do to help the homeless kept them up all night, they were awake until 6am! Jump in the Sea for the Homeless is one of the ideas they came up with. 

On Sunday March 17th at 11am you are invited to come to Helens Bay Beach and jump in the sea. You can get sponsored by your friends and family, or donate a small amount of pocket money.

Title: Crowdfunder for Homeless Youth

Description:
We are holding a fundraiser at The Galleon Bar in Blackpool to help raise funds for Streetlife  a homeless charity in Blackpool.

I have created this page as i know there are lots of people who would love to help raise funds but for whatever reason are unable to attend our fundraiser or buy any raffle tickets.

A huge thank you to everyone who have donated prizes for our raffle. I will be advertising and thanking you personally on Facebook!

Young people are dying in this freezing weather and some just need a little help to get back to where they need to be. We can give them this help by fundraising and donating warm clothing, quilts or sleeping bags. These can be left at The Galleon Bar and I will be distributing them myself to the people that need them.

Please help me to help the homeless people living on the streets we live on.

Thank you so much to everyone involved and Stephen Pierre for allowing us to use The Galleon Bar for our fundraiser, making a donation of £100 direct to Streetlife and offering a free wine reception, buffet and raffle prizes.
Title: Streetlife Fundraiser for The Homeless At The Galleon Bar in Blackpool

Description:
Every year since 2010, more people have found themselves sleeping on our streets. StreetLink exists to help connect people sleeping rough to local support services by enabling members of the public to send an alert when they see someone sleeping out.

Since we launched, over 150,000 alerts have been sent about people sleeping rough and thousands of people have been offered the support they need to escape rough sleeping.

Hey everyone,

 So this weekend Saturday 28th I will be sleeping outside to raise awareness and raise money for the homeless please donate to this cause it’s such an amazing organisation and I would appreciate any donations at all  Thank you 🙏🏻 Wish me luck 


-Homeless Project Scotland is a fledgling charity, set up in October 2019 by a handful of volunteers that wanted to give homeless people on the streets of our towns and cities hot drinks and food during the harsh winter nights.Initially we set out with backpacks of flasks and sandwiches walking the streets of Glasgow and Edinburgh to ensure that anyone found struggling was able at least to get a hot drink and something to eat. Within a short period of time, we managed to recruit a team of volunteers who began to distribute a selection of food, essential toiletries and warm clothes. We were fortunate to enlist the support from major companies such as Aldi, Asda, Tesco, Morrisons and Marks & Spencer, who have kindly donated supplies of food which we collect during the day and then distribute to homeless shelters throughout Glasgow, Edinburgh and Lanarkshire in the evenings.

Title: Molly Up A Mountain

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Myself, my mum, Diana, and my partner, Callum have joined forces to create a team united to try and end homeless and poverty in our local community.. We’re officially callerd ‘Welliott against Homelessness’ and want to raise funds to support those in our local community! 

On Friday 12th November, we will be travelling to Brighton to sleep on the fields of St Peters Church for the night. For the night, which will be very chilly to say the least, we’ll be building our own accommodation out of cardboard boxes and tape - where to sleep MUST be built using materials we have on hand to us. 

Money raised will go towards the charity’s work (Off the Fence) such as, their Anti-Freeze Project, which offers a range of care including food, sleeping bags, clothes and laundry services at its day centre and emotional support the the homeless. 

We want to raise awareness and leave a positive piece of change for those in our immediate local community! Please support us if you can spare a pound. Everyone deserves a home and it’s important we all try to leave a positive footprint behind! 

Thank you from team Welliott in advance!

Love, 

Emily, Diana and Callum x

Title: wendy's Herts Young Homeless in a Sleepout page

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I have had a hell of a life experience throughout the years. And a few times, I was very close to be homeless for various reasons. It made me appreciate my home and made me realise how lucky we are to have a place called home. I was lucky enough to meet people along my path, who helped me to find a home. 

But so many people aren't so lucky. They sleep rough, and some don't make through the winter. They are misunderstood and ignored. They are the forgotten part of our society. 

Whilst so many people fundraise for so many different causes, in memory of their loved ones, we sometimes forget about the unfortunates who are still with us. All they need is a little bit more love, from us.

So please, if you can, donate. Donate as a Christmas or  a Diwali donation. Donate for a good cause. Donate to celebrate someone's memory. Donate to celebrate how we can be the champions of humanity. 

Donate so we can help those who are less fortunate than us. Believe me, whatever we put in, it helps. You will make a difference.  I promise you.

Title: Half Marathon for Homeless

Description:
I would like to thank each and everyone of you for taking the time to read my story.

Being homeless in itself  is just awful let alone at Christmas time . Crisis homeless charity really is something else , I've worked previous years as a general worker cleaning toilets washing up serving food tea and coffee , making up beds and many more tasks  but most importantly sitting down with the guests talking at length and in depth. 

Not all homeless people  choose to  be homeless, variably  people fall on hard  times for  a  million  different reasons  , they may have mental health issues or addictions they all have their own unique story and each and every guest is important. 

Anyway I could talk for ever about  it all  , I want to help again this year but this time I've gained myself a new trade as a barber so yep I'll be cutting hair and hopefully making them feel good  🙂

I need your help now to make a bigger impact , it costs around £30 to feed just one homeless person on Christmas day .

Please take a moment to think about it , I want sponsorship to help me raise money,  every little helps .

I know it's Christmas charity begins at home and all that.

Anything would be better than nothing ..

Thanks again  big love to all  Merry Christmas to you all x

Title: Ramadan - Feed the homeless

Description:
Homeless Project Scotland is a fledgling charity, set up in October 2019 by a handful of volunteers that wanted to give homeless people on the streets of our towns and cities hot drinks and food during the harsh winter nights.

Initially they set out with backpacks of flasks and sandwiches walking the streets of Glasgow and Edinburgh to ensure that anyone found struggling was able at least to get a hot drink and something to eat. Within a short period of time, the organisation managed to recruit a team of volunteers who began to distribute a selection of food, essential toiletries and warm clothes.

Since then, they have enlisted the support from major companies such as Aldi, Asda, Tesco, Morrisons and Marks & Spencer, who kindly donate supplies of food which are collected during the day and then distribute to homeless shelters throughout Glasgow, Edinburgh and Lanarkshire in the evenings.

Anyone who saw the above picture of the huge line of homeless people waiting to be fed one night under the Hielanman's Umbrella recently couldn’t fail to have been shocked. I know I was. It’s been an issue in Glasgow for a long time, but things have clearly got much, much worse

That soup kitchen is being ran by Homeless Project Scotland, an organisation completely made up of volunteers. Not one person is taking a wager despite the tireless work they do in and around the city with every penny donated going directly to people who are in the most desperate of need.

Things are rough all round at the moment, but I can’t stand back and do nothing knowing this is going on right on our doorsteps. So a group of us have got together, with more joining every day, to walk the West Highland Way and raise as much as possible for this amazing charity, who need support now more than ever, due to the impact of COVID-restrictions.

We are planning on doing the walk over several days in April, lockdown willing. It will be socially distanced, compliant with all regulations and hopefully by the end of it we will have hit our group target of £50,000.

We know things are tight, but if you can spare anything at all, be assured it will be making a huge difference to someone’s life.

Even if you can’t donate, a share will do. It all counts. And if you want to join in the walk itself, we’d love to have you along.

In the meantime, let’s do what we can to help the people who help everyone else.

Cheers

Ryan Blair

Title: Let's end homelessness!

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit this JustGiving page.

All donations go directly to Shelter and directly help people who are homeless or in bad housing in the UK.

Jeremy Corbyn was determined to end homelessness in the UK following a seeming rise in this shocking flaw in our society.  It's a scar clearly visible on our streets - brutal, dangerous, inhumane and seemingly solvable.

Many are outraged at the election result and feel like homelessness will increase under Boris Johnson.  Let us all put our money where our mouth is and take direct action - be it £5 or £5,000, every pound counts and is even more valuable to those in need on the streets or in substandard housing.

Many will be much better off under the Tories, be this marginal gains by keeping marriage tax allowance (£250 year for couples under £50k), or over £5,000 a year if you're earning £150k.  Why not donate some of these savings to Shelter in recognition of Jeremy Corbyn's noble vision to end homelessness in the UK.

Title: Unite against Homelessness

Description:
In 2016 I met my most faithful and trustworthy friend. They say a dog is a man's best friend, well its also a womans best friend. 

I adopted Joey from Dogs Trust 3 months before I found out I was pregnant with Riley. When we found out I was pregnant we needed to train Joey ASAP as he wasn't confident and wasn't supposed to be around young children. 

In December 2016 I was utterly heartbroken when we had to give him to Dogs Trust. He was there for me in one of the most hardest times of my life and I felt like I was giving up on him. 

I have never stopped following him, his new owner has let me follow posts on Instagram and I will always call him my dog. 

Dogs Trust do a wonderful job of looking after Dogs that have no home, they make sure their dogs go to the right owners, there is a long process to adopt a dog with them which I truly love as hopefully the dog will not end up with the wrong type of owner. 

So please donate to my first half marathon race in Cardiff on October 4th 2020. Let's raise as much money as we can so the charity can carry on with their fabulous work.

Title: Helping the homeless at Christmas

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm working on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and Boxing day and trying to raise enough money to provide at least 30 people with Christmas support. (30 equates to 1 person for every hour I work at the shelter)

Whilst we enjoy warm houses, family and friends and wonderful meals over the festive season many others in England, Scotland and Wales will struggle.

Please spare whatever you can and help make a difference to someone's life this Christmas.

Donating £26.08 at Christmas to Crisis will help one person to have:

* a hot, delicious Christmas dinner and other food over the festive period

* access to doctors and free medical services,  lawyers for free advice, opticians for tests and free glasses, hairdressers for free haircuts and dentists for free treatments. All who donate their time over a 9 day period in each of the pop up shelters

* a warm safe place to sleep in pop up shelters all over the UK

* advice and support re benefits, learning and ways to try and help start a new life off the street

For my friends overseas please consider supporting local charities that do the same.

Many thanks

Sharon﻿
Title: Helping the homeless at Christmas

Description:
DIG DEEP THIS WINTER 

When your lying in your nice warm bed or sitting by the fireplace this Christmas time with a glass of baileys the warm glow of that Christmas tree around you, heating on counting down the days to Christmas 

Spare a thaught for the less fortunate, the people with no roof over there heads no food on there table, no family to share the holidays with, just the cold hard floor & the fear & dread of what the next day could bring. It could happen to anyone 

It could happen to you, your children, your perants, your friends, brothers, sisters 

Just one thing happens and everything can spiral out of control & you have nothing left ITS NOT FAIR IF WE CAN DO SOMETHING WE SHOULD, IT COULD BE ANYONE. SO GIVE MONEY TO CENTRE POINT SO THEY CAN DO SOME GOOD IN THIS WORLD, ITS CHRISTMAS FOR GODS SAKE NO-ONE SHOULD SPEND IT ALONE IN THE COLD!!!!!!!!
