Title: Help The Homeless This Christmas

Description:
If you watched my Instagram story last week, you will remember I was approached by a homeless man asking me to help take him off the streets. Not money, not food, but to genuinely get him off the street and it really broke my heart. I didn’t know what to do and was advised by lots of people to visit streetlink as they can find him and help. So instead of trying to tackle this huge problem alone, I have decided to support charities like this one, to actually help tackle the homelessness issue. My end goal is to take people off the street completely, not just to make their lives on the street more comfortable. Please help me with this - so in 2020 we can try to get as many people off the streets as possible.

Every year since 2010, more people have found themselves sleeping on our streets. StreetLink exists to help connect people sleeping rough to local support services by enabling members of the public to send an alert when they see someone sleeping out.Since we launched, over 150,000 alerts have been sent about people sleeping rough and thousands of people have been offered the support they need to escape rough sleeping.
Title: Raising money for the homeless

Description:
World Homeless Day is all about drawing attention to the needs of the most vulnerable people locally. We have all seen the impact of COVID-19 on vulnerable people across Hampshire  on top of the issues they already face day-to-day. World Homeless Day gives us a chance to reflect on how those less fortunate than ourselves have been affected by the COVID-19 situation.
With less than a month to go till WHD, we are asking our supporters to help share some of the stories weve posted during the past 12 months to help share news about the work we are doing to end homelessness. You can find those stories HERE. (https://ssj.org.uk/2020-march-to-august/)
Title: World Homeless Day

Description: It's hard to protect yourself from the coronavirus outbreak when you're homeless. People who are sleeping rough are more likely to suffer from respiratory conditions. They can't wash their hands. And if someone is sleeping rough or in a crowded night shelter, it's impossible to self-isolate. We are raising vital funds to support Crisis in their work to help homeless people. There's only one thing that's certain in these uncertain times. It's a time to pull together and help each other. Any gift, big or small, will make a difference at this time of crisis.
Title: Helping the Homeless this Christmas

Description:
We easily forget how ridiculously fortunate we are, taking for granted holidays, jobs, food, clothes, toys and a nice house. We spend money on gifts people don't need, probably don't want. Anyway, not to preach, I'm setting this up as an alternative to donate your money where its needed, and hopefully one day our kids will realise how important this is - giving, not receiving, trying to help simply not taking. 

The Booth Centre is a community centre run with and for people affected by homelessness. ​The Booth Centre provides a warm welcome, an opportunity to belong, to gain a purpose and rebuild lives. Our programme includes activities such as volunteering, creative projects and sports, as well as training and help to gain employment. We also support people to improve health and wellbeing, to access emergency accommodation, and to secure and maintain a permanent home.

The idea is to run this for all of 2021 and see how much we can donate to help homelessness.
Title: Helping homelessness in Manchester

Description:
The one and only Sam Sumner will be completing a sponsored Sleep
Out on Friday 6th November. He will build a shelter in his back
garden and spend the entire night sleeping outside. What an absolute hero.

We also have Tracey Sharp and Matthew Witchard that have volunteered to reflect the food side of being homeless and they will be completing a three day challenge and living on just £2 per day for 3 days.

We have a target of £500, and it would be SO great if we could get to this target! Also, if you would like to take part, just shout and  I can add your name to the AWESOME list!
Title: World Homeless Day

Description:
My name is Jimmy.

I am 9 years old and I am raising money to help the homeless.

I live in London and on my way to school each day I see suffering people on the road near my school.

I feel like they should lead as good a life as everyone else.

Any donation helps



entrepoint supports more than 9,200 homeless young people each year in London, Manchester, Sunderland and Yorkshire, and through partner charities across the UK.
Title: The homeless depend on you

Description: The Salvation Army is a registered charity and church working in 120 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, older people, homeless people and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction.

Title: Centrepoint - youth homelessness

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving Page, I ask for you to consider donating this Christmas to help another person or family in need,  giving others a better chance towards a happier healthier and more enriched life in  2019. 

Hull Homeless Community Project exists to support all those affected by or worried about homelessness. Providing advice, support, services and educational campaigns in Hull and the surrounding area.   Homelessness can be prevented, and with care support, family crisis  and mental health services on offer as well as practical help to those in need of a home.  - all this alongside being a critical friend for those feeling isolated to give them the best chance in remaining in their homes.

Not only does the charity do all this, their founder gives his time  to educate others on the issues of homelessness to local colleges, schools, communities, trainee nurses and many others. 

Families with young children, young care leavers, teenagers, people who have suffered from slavery, women who have suffered domestic violence  all amongst the clients of this charity.  

Thank you for reading and considering a donation this Christmas. 

Paula x.
Title: Supporting Prevention of Homelessness

Description:
EMMAUS: SUPPORTING PEOPLE OUT OF HOMELESSNESS

Sheila believed whole-heartedly in the aims of Emmaus: to (her words) "give a man a bed for the night, and a reason to get out of it". She was a trustee of Emmaus Coventry, always fighting to give more chances and to keep the door open to the most vulnerable people. Though Sheila was always inclined to offer cash to anyone asking on the street, she knew that it would take longer term investment and support to help anyone get back on their feet and integrated into work and community, and that's what Emmaus provides.

Description: According to the last Shelter report, at least 320,000 people are homeless, almost 5,000 are rough sleeping (likely to be a huge underestimate) and 726 people died homeless in England and Wales in 2018 (a 22% rise from 2017). Title: Support the UK homeless

Description:
On holiday last year, we came across some homeless children. Both Emie and Hughie found this very upsetting and we always promised we would help them to raise some money to help the children. Leave your name on your donation here or let me know you have bought a ticket so we don’t miss you out 👍

Title: Girls for Action on homelessness

Description:
The Ethero team has decided to do 160 miles in a non-stop week of walking. Starting from Telford on Monday the 11th of June and hopefully finishing back in Telford on Friday the 15th of June having been to Coventry, Burton and Stoke on the way.

This year we are proudly supporting Help 4 Homeless Veterans and the amazing work they do.

Help 4 Homeless Veterans rent old run down houses from councils around the U K and renovate them so that they are ready to house ex forces veterans who are homeless.

Ethero Strategic Staffing will hopefully be able to pay for a house for a
whole year for ex-military staff who may have mental or physical problems caused by the service they have given.

Our goal is to raise £2500 but we're aiming for more! So any donations would be greatly appreciated.

Cambridge Street Aid is a charity that provides grants for those who are homeless in the local area. These grants go towards helping people get off , and stay off, the streets.

Description:
Every day, nearly 200,000 households across Great Britain go without the safety or comfort of their own home. Vital funds are needed to tackle the causes of homelessness and get people the help they need quickly.  

This World Homeless Day we're taking action to raise awareness of homelessness and the right for every person to have somewhere safe and secure to call home. Every penny you donate will help end homelessness for good.
Title: World Homeless Day

Description: Eight of us (Brian and Kathryn Clapp, Peter Hession, Paul Bristow, Sean Coursey, James Sherratt, Jon Wyatt and Martin Long) have signed up to participate in the Blenheim Palace Triathlon on Sunday September 12th, 2021. Paul instigated this, after an evening of drinks at the Alex just under a year ago. We are all linked by having children who have been at Bishop Gilpin Primary School. None of us, apart from Paul have done a Triathlon before; we are all over fifty and in various states of decay Set in the grounds of a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Blenheim Palace is full of history and surrounded by beautiful British gardens and nature. It is described, by those that know, as the most stunning triathlon in the UK. The course starts with a beginner friendly, fresh lake open water swim for 750m, followed by a gently undulating bike course along completely closed roads for 19.8 km. And to finish off, we enjoy beautiful scenery as we run around the Queen’s pool for 5.4km! We have decided to raise funds for Faith in Action Merton Homelessness Project (FiA) something we have all volunteered or supported in the past As an example of where your donation goes • £5 per month pays for two Square Meals for a service user • £10 pays for razors for two weeks to enable service users to shower and shave • £17 pays the cost of one average service user’s day at the Drop-In • £30 pays for two new, warm sleeping bags which FiA give out to those rough sleeping • £60 pays for a month’s worth of the warm socks and underclothes FiA service users need • £100 pays for a UK passport, providing ID needed for job applications.
Title: Pauls Triathlon for the Homeless

Description:
Single Homeless Project is a London-wide charity, that help single Londoners by preventing homelessness, providing support and accommodation, promoting wellbeing, enhancing opportunity, and being a voice for change.

From supporting people in crisis to helping people take the final steps towards independence and employment, SHP make a difference to 10,000 lives every year across all 32 boroughs.

Visit SHP’s website: https://www.shp.org.uk/

This year, the Centrus team are joining London's iconic 5k Santa Run on 1st December to raise money for SHP. Donations are greatly appreciated!

To get into the festive spirit or to see how fast you can run dressed as Santa - you can join us at 'Santa in the City' by clicking here.
Title: Centrus take part in London's 'Santa Run' for Single Homeless Project

Description:
Each day across all 32 London boroughs, Single Homeless Project works with individuals to tackle the underlying causes of homelessness, such as poor mental health or drug and alcohol dependency.

With 40 years of expertise and a London-wide reach, we make a difference to more than 10,000 lives every year. Often that means being there for people at a critical time whether to prevent their eviction or help them off the street; to get them into drug or alcohol treatment or support them with their mental health; or to help them find a job and a flat so that they can take the final steps to living on their own.

Perhaps most important of all, our work restores hope to people who might otherwise feel forgotten, left behind or written off, providing crucial footholds in their recovery journey from which they can go on to build independent and fulfilling lives.

Description:
Hi, I’m Ryan. Yeah him.


This December, I’ll be doing my ownversion of the 12 days of Christmas – Doing 5k a day for 12 consecutive daysfor the charity Helping Homeless Veterans UK, who dedicate their time to helping homeless veteransget their lives back on track. To quote Grandad from Only Fools: ‘They promisedus homes fit for heroes, but they gave us heroes for for homes’. And,particularly at Christmas, those who risked it all for us should be given aproper meal and warmth during the harshest months of the year.


Thank you for reading, and for anydonations that you see fit to give to this fantastic cause.
Title: Ryan's 12 Days of 5k for Helping Homeless Veterans UK

Description:
Winter 2021-22 is going to be extra tough.

Wycombe Homeless Connection needs our help to make sure there will be help and hope this winter for anyone who needs it.

Locally, efforts to keep everyone in have just ended and more people will need a safe place to stay this winter.

The huge challenge they face is keeping everyone who doesnt have a home off the street, in suitable accommodation, with everything they need to stay healthy and well, while helping them find a more suitable, more permanent home. All this while there continues to be a severe shortage of suitable and affordable homes meaning moving on from emergency accommodation can be incredibly difficult.

The good news is because of your support, WHC can be here to help.
Title: Wycombe Homeless Connection's Big Sleepout 2021: At Home

Description:
Tickets: £2 for 1 | £5 for 4 

Firstly... Hello and thankyou for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page!

For those who are new to New Chapter, we are an award winning FMCG and Retail recruitment agency. We were established in 2004 and now have teams in both Leeds and London recruiting for mid to senior management and board level professionals across a number of high profile clients. 

We are proud to have recently become a corporate partner of End Youth Homelessness, a UK-wide charity who help, on average, 40,365 young people per year get back on their feet through four key areas; housing, health, work & prevention. 

As a recruitment business we want to help put a particular focus of our support and fundraising efforts into the employability fund, an area of the charity which works to help young homeless people secure long term employment through specialist coaching and resources. 

After coming together with clients we have received some extremely kind donations to help us organise this raffle, meaning some great prizes up for grabs! 

We hope that together, with your kind donations and participation in the raffle, we can raise a great amount for the EYH charity at a particularly hard time of year for young, homeless individuals. 

Thank you & Good luck!

Tickets: £2 for 1 | £5 for 4

Title: New Chapter Christmas Charity Raffle for End Youth Homelessness

Description:
Homeless Project Scotland is a fledgling charity, set up in October 2019 by a handful of volunteers that wanted to give homeless people on the streets  of our towns and cities hot drinks and food during the harsh winter nights.

Initially we set out with backpacks of flasks and sandwiches walking the streets of Glasgow and Edinburgh to ensure that anyone found struggling was able at least to get a hot drink and something to eat. Within a short period of time, we managed to recruit a team of volunteers who began to distribute a selection of food, essential toiletries and warm clothes.  We were  fortunate to enlist the support from major companies such as Aldi, Asda, Tesco, Morrisons and Marks & Spencer, who have kindly donated supplies of food which we collect  during the day and then distribute to homeless shelters throughout Glasgow, Edinburgh and Lanarkshire in the evenings.

Title: Roger & Sam's Herts Young Homeless Sleepout page

Description: The Royston Rough Sleepers team has been sleeping out on December nights for CUF’s work with the homeless since 2017. Numbers fluctuate; this year there may be ten of us. It’s quite a harsh thing to do, always cold, sometimes wet, once a bitter frost and a full moon, and though we have tarpaulins and sleeping bags and mats, and dinner inside us and breakfast to look forward to, still it gives some idea of what it must be to face this night after night. So it’s marvellous that so many people are joining in. If you can, do please support us.
Title: Marks Page

Description:
SCS are committed to creating a long-lasting social legacy, including working with the most vulnerable across our areas. We have chosen to partner with three local charities that support food poverty, young homeless people and suicide awareness. 

City Harvest rescue surplus food from retailers and manufacturers which would otherwise be sent to landfills, and repurpose for those who need it most in our boroughs. 

Distributing over 200,00 meals a week to over 350 London community projects, including homeless shelters, soup kitchens, children's programmes, mental health support schemes, and refuges. Every £1 donated will feed four people.
Title: City Harvest London

Description:
SCS are committed to creating a long-lasting social legacy for our communities, including with the most vulnerable across our areas. We have chosen to partner with three local charities that support food poverty, young homeless people and suicide awareness. 

Maytree provide a unique residential service for people in suicidal crisis so they can talk about their suicidal thoughts and behaviour. They offer a free four-night five-day one-off stay to adults over the age of 18 from across the UK. Their aim is to provide a sage, confidential, non-medical environment for their guests. Somewhere their guests can explore their thoughts and feelings, and feel heard with compassion and without judgement.
Title: Maytree

Description:

We have chosen to raise awareness and funds for Single Homeless Project, a charity who work to prevent homelessness and help vulnerable people to transform their lives. This is something we are extremely passionate about. 

Any donation you can make will be hugely appreciated. Please help us support this amazing charity and raise as much money for them as possible. 

We wanted to finally shout out our Business Mentors from Praxis IFM who have helped make this event possible!

Thank you from Team Homeless Haven at Addey & Stanhope Schooll!

Description:
Barnabus is a Manchester Christian Homeless Charity bringing hope and transformation to people experiencing homelessness and rough sleeping in our City for 30 years.

We empower and equip people experiencing homelessness back into a home and independent living with the life skills they need to succeed. We do this through our Outreach, Support Centre, Healthcare and Supported Resettlement Tenancy Scheme. We help with accommodation, recovery from addictions and supporting physical and mental health needs. 

#endinghomelessnesstogether

Title: Wendy's page- Sleepout 2021

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I love a good charitable cause and with the rise of young adults becoming homeless in a first world country now is the time to help put a stop to this. I will be putting myself out there - so here I am committing myself to sleep rough on 19th November (yes in the cold come rain or shine) in support of Herts Young Homeless. No tent, no heater - just sleeping bags, cardboard and hot drinks. 

Herts Young Homeless support vulnerable young people who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, working with them to achieve the best possible outcomes.

What they say - "Our focus is on preventing homelessness - from education in schools and family mediation through to supporting 16-24 year olds in their first homes or caring for adults of all ages who have mental health issues and housing needs.

Our services empower young people to be able to deal with the difficult situations in their lives, giving them the ability and confidence to 'do it themselves' and ultimately find stability."

Please support me and give to this amazing cause.

Title: The Homeless To Home Challenge 2021

Description:
Thank you  for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The WHP Sleep Out is an annual fundraising challenge, where people in our community come together to raise funds and awareness for Windsor’s homelessness charity. 

We won’t fully experience what it is like to sleep rough, but it does open our eyes to the experience that so many people in our community and around the UK find themselves in every day.

How can my fundraising help?

  • £10 - Advice for a person experiencing or facing homelessness, or other difficulties, at WHP drop-in centre

  • £50 – Three phones with credit – allowing guests to keep crucial appointments with their support teams, such as the local council, the Drug and Alcohol service, or NHS services

  • £75 – A week of hot lunches for all our guests at the WHP drop-in centre

  • £150 – A move for a guest into a new home – including all the basics needed to make a house a home

  • £300 – Nine hours of counselling, for one guest to begin to work through past life-events and traumas that have brought them to where they are today

Title: Liz's World Homeless Day 2021

Description:
We have been set a challenge by David Tovey to help make a dent in homelessness. In the UK around 280,000 people are thought to be homeless, meaning that one in every 200 people are without a home. We have decided to raise money for Padley who provide services to the most vulnerable people in Derby. We will each be walking/running 200km in October, to represent the 1 in every 200 people who don’t have a home. We would be grateful for any support in helping us to achieve the goal we have set. 

Padley has been working in the City of Derby since 1985 providing homelessness prevention support. We work with those most vulnerable, disadvantage and socially excluded in our city through our day centre at padley house, supported flats through our padley pathways and food offer of emergency food parcels and hot food service from our Padley Pantry. We aim to provide people with safe spaces to learn essential life skills and build their confidence and wellbeing so they can lead more independent happier and healthier life.
Title: Stepping up to the David Tovey Challenge

Title: Jennys page

Description:
It's nearly that time of year again... CHRISTMAS and for many of us that means cosying up in the warmth watching Christmas films and doing some last minute wrapping. For others,  this time of year means dark nights, unbearable cold and the fear of going hungry another day. Recently, I have had the pleasure of meeting a number of lovely people,  who have unfortunately  found themselves in difficult times, consequently making them homeless. Talking to these people, has highlighted the hardship they endure on a daily basis to simply survive. One person I met told me of how he became homeless (through no fault of his own)  and how he feels embarrassed asking strangers for spare change...and even more embarrassed when they ignore him. I have to admit this broke my heart. Imagine being cold, hungry and imagine feeling lonely with no one to turn to. 

Therefore, this year we would like to give a helping hand by raising funds to provide shelter, food and warmth for the homeless people of Chester and beyond. To do this we are holding a competition to WIN 3 beautiful Sterling Silver SJBH bracelets. Entry cost is £2 per entry and 100% of the proceeds will be donated directly to the brilliant charity 'Chester Aid To The Homeless'. You can enter as many times as you like, so for 2 chances donate £4 and so on! Our aim is to raise £200+ for this amazing cause, which will help to give many homeless people across Chester a much brighter future. 

Competition draw will be made on Friday 22rd December 2017 on our Facebook page. When entering please ensure that you have contacted us via our Facebook page to provide contact details otherwise we will not be able to let you know if you  win! 


https://www.facebook.com/silverjewellerybyhannah/
Title: GIVE A HELPING HAND TO THE HOMELESS.

Description:
Between the ages of 17 and 22, I was homeless. I was in and out of youth hostels, I slept on park benches, in shop doorways, on roof tops. I relied on food banks and kind donations from the general public at times. I can remember the Christmas of 2012, I woke up on Christmas day in a place called Yeovil Foyer, it was a youth hostel place for 16-25 year olds to go when they had nowhere left to turn, it was great because it kept me off the streets but I struggled to get on with other people that lived there and the staff, I felt isolated and I didn't see a future for myself at all. Since then I have had many more times of being on the streets on cold, wet, horrible dark nights and I understand what it's like to feel like you have nothing and nobody left but there is hope and we can make sure others do not have to go through this alone.

As I type this it is almost Christmas day of 2017 and I live with my mother and brother in a warm home so now I would like to try and raise as much money as possible for the homeless and help them gain the hope I now have.

Description:
Last week my Husband and I came across this envelope with some money and a card inside.. Our 6 year old daughter Sophie had picked up a mail shot from Crisis UK and after reading the leaflet, took it upon herself to respond to them as shown in the photos below! She took some money from her money box and enclosed it inside the envelope and left it by the front door ready to post off the next day!

Adam and I are so proud of Sophie, she is such a sweet, kindhearted, caring and loving little girl.

We have set up a Just Giving page for Crisis UK (help the homeless) on Sophies behalf, so she can start collecting donations to help the homeless people.

£26.08. Reserves 1 place at Crisis UK at Christmas:
A warm welcome, three nutritious, hot meals daily including Christmas dinner, a chance to shower, freshen up and get clean clothes, a health check and treatment from a doctor, optician and dentist, expert help with mental health and addiction problems, advice on housing and employment PLUS access to Crisis’s year-round services for training and support in the year ahead.

Please can we kindly ask you all to donate to this very worthy cause and share this post so Sophie can raise lots of money for Crisis UK.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We serve people from all backgrounds and ages distributing between 400-500 food parcels over a 4 day period. This project is self funded through the generosity of the public and our volunteers, with no funding from governmental departments. As a result we are making a plea for funding to continue the project for the year. The cost per feed day is £180. We serve every Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Sunday in Birmingham. If you want to donate towards 1 day please kindly do so and stipulate the date/day you wish to sponsor in the comments. Title: Birmingham Project - Feed for a day challenge!

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We've all seen the increase in the number of homeless people on the streets of Cardiff. This is my small way of doing something about it rather than walking on by.

Please help me reach my target of £250, which is enough to feed everyone staying at Huggard's shelter for a whole day.

I've chosen to raise this money by fasting for a whole day because it is during the month of Ramadan, when Muslim people do not drink or eat anything during daylight hours for one whole month to remember those who have less than us. I will be doing the same for 18 hours on Thursday 7th June. Breakfast at 4am and nothing until dinner at 10pm.

 I teach many students who observe this ritual and I hope by doing this I can show my solidarity with the Muslim community of Cardiff while raising much-needed funds for a vital service.

Title: Chris's Sleep Out For The Homeless 2018

Description:
While the snow can be both fun and beautiful for many of us, it will be deadly for others. The large homeless population in Cambridge are suffering due to the extreme weather conditions. Without adequate clothes and sleeping bags, rough sleepers in Cambridge will get very ill and in extreme cases, some may die.


As students, we have the power to prevent this from happening. Because of this, Cambridge RAG have been in touch with Wintercomfort, a local homelessness charity, who suggested an emergency monetary collection.


We therefore implore you to do what you can to help the most vulnerable in our community by donating to Wintercomfort. While £10 is the suggested donation, we understand that some people may not be able to afford this, so please donate what you can - everything will go a really long way and all donations are massively appreciated. Equally, if you can afford to donate more than £10, please please do!



Wintercomfort are a day centre for homeless and vulnerably housed individuals in Cambridge open all year round. The charity provide welfare services, learning and development programmes and two successful social enterprises providing employment & training to homeless individuals. Currently the centre welcomes on average 61 individuals a day, around 22,000 visits every year.


Message from Wintercomfort:
"During the cold weather we continue to be open and our work is of greater importance during the exceptionally cold winter months. We are most grateful for any help great or small."



Find out more about Winter Comfort’s work through their website:

http://wintercomfort.org.uk/
Title: Emergency Winter Homelessness Appeal

Description:
St. Mungo’s believe that we all have a right to have a place to call home.

They help thousands of people every year rebuild their lives from being homeless and vulnerable into a secure place they can sleep each night and call home.  From complexed mental illness support to families on the brink of eviction.

Streets to Kitchen Project,  Bristol – We are raising money to support this amazing St. Mungo’s project!

The course will teach cookery and food service skills to people who have lived on the streets and been rough sleepers on the streets of Bristol and Bath.  It will provide a vocational qualification in food safety certificate to help them gain experience on how to cook, look after themselves well, build confidence and get them back into the work place. The weekly sessions will give clients confidence in and out of the kitchen. They will develop vital life skills, improved wellbeing and be encouraged to cook for others, potentially in a professional capacity. The training will initially take place in the Recovery College in the New Street Hub - a familiar environment for them. 

They will learn a couple of simple recipes and be encouraged to eat
together at the end of each session.  As they progress they’ll begin to
cook for other service users and staff, with the potential to reinvigorate the onsite kitchen.  It is hoped this will develop into a social enterprise where they will generate a small income for the centre and learn additional skills such as front of house and customer service.

£700 is needed to buy appliances are needed for the kitchen!
Title: Everyone has a story: Please help us break the stigma of homelessness!

Title: andrew's Feed the homeless  during  lockdown

Description: Anyone who saw the image of the huge line of homeless people waiting to be fed one night under the Hielanman's Umbrella recently couldn’t fail to have been shocked. We know we were. It’s been an issue in Glasgow for a long time, but things have clearly gotten much, much worse. That soup kitchen is being ran by Homeless Project Scotland, an organisation completely made up of volunteers. Not one person is taking a wage despite the tireless work they do in and around the city, with every penny donated going directly to people who are in the most desperate of need. Things are rough all round at the moment, but we can’t stand back and do nothing, knowing that this is going on right on our doorstep. As a result, a group of us have gotten together, with more joining every day, to walk the West Highland Way and raise as much as possible for this amazing charity who need support now more than ever due to the impact of COVID-restrictions. Lockdown willing, we are planning on doing the walk over several days in April. It will be socially distanced, compliant with all regulations and hopefully by the end of it we will have hit our group target of £50,000. The money raised will go towards equipping Homeless Project Scotland with a custom-fitted outreach vehicle. This will vastly improve their capability to supply food, essentials and support to those most in need both in Glasgow and across the country. We know things are tight, but if you can spare anything at all, please be assured it will be making a huge difference to someone’s life. Even if you can’t donate, a share will do. It all counts and if you want to join in the walk itself, we’d love to have you along. You can do one day, the whole thing or anything in between. It’s up to you. Get it touch with us through this page and we can talk you through it. In the meantime, let’s do what we can to help the people who help everyone else.

Title: Ian's Helping Cardiff's homeless this Christmas

Description:
Investing In Future Generations

SAP Concur has chosen to support the charity End Youth Homelessness as part of this initiative. 

EYH is a UK-wide movement of local charities working with over 30,000 homeless young people. They support them on every step of their journey from homelessness to independence.

As well as helping young people find a place to call home, EYH helps young people work towards their career and education goals in an effort to end youth homelessness by equipping them with the skills they need to live independently.

The team will be breaking a sweat to raise money for this fantastic cause, keep an eye on our social feed on Thursday, 6th June to get involved or donate here!
Title: SPIN FOR EYH

Description:
"McLaren Construction engages with the local community wherever we work, to leave a positive legacy. St John’s Development has made hugely positives steps towards tackling homelessness in Greater Manchester. As a local employer with projects in the region, we want to play our part in increasing awareness, creating jobs and raising money for this valuable cause."


The St Johns Homelessness Initiative is a joint commitment from all organisations involved in the development to contribute towards ending homelessness through; awareness-raising, inclusive employment, and fundraising. This is a pioneering project which has created a meaningful and sustainable model of collaboration between developers, contractors, supply chain organisations, the city Council and local charities. As far as we are aware, this is the largest single commitment from these industries towards the reduction of homelessness in the UK and we hope that it will be replicated. We are working with the Manchester Homelessness Partnership and Big Change MCR to ensure that our efforts and your donations are channelled to where they are most needed. This fund will support potentially hundreds of people who are homeless in Manchester and will prevent more people from becoming homeless.

Title: Mandy's Yoga in support of the homeless of Warrington

Description:
As volunteer Trustees of Housing Justice, we’re taking on The £1k Challenge. Between us, we’re raising £1,000 to support rough sleepers and those in housing need. Right now, that work is more important than ever.

Please, dig deep and donate today to help us reach our goal!

Thanks to generous donations from people like you, Housing Justice supports thousands of disadvantaged people every year. In 2020 our incredible staff team pulled out the stops to support people through the crisis - in the spring alone, when the first lockdown started, they helped to get 700 of London’s rough sleepers into safe hotel accommodation.

As if the homelessness crisis we’re facing wasn’t bad enough, we’re now entering a winter with a recession - and the impact of Covid-19 on jobs is going to make things so much worse. 

Our amazing team at Housing Justice will do everything they can to support people who are facing homelessness, but they rely on the kindness of people like you to continue. So please, will you help us hit our £1,000 target?

Thank you so much for supporting us.

Mandy, Chrishanti, Sarah, Sarah, Richard, Aidan and Joe

PS You can take The £1K Challenge too! Visit: HousingJustice.org.uk/1kchallenge
Title: Help us raise a thousand pounds to tackle homelessness!

Description:
There is a homelessness crisis in Belfast. Last year, over 150 people registered as homeless in Northern Ireland had their applications for social housing closed because they died before they could be housed.

Winter is coming. As we come into the colder months and Christmas, I’m asking for donations for NI’s leading homeless charity, The Simon Community.

The Simon Community are Northern Ireland’s leading homelessness charity. With 22 emergency and temporary accommodation based services and warm 369 beds, over 2,400 people can vouch for the crucial residential services they provide, along with the thousands of people who call their 24 hr. emergency helpline each year.

All money raised will go towards homelessness prevention, emergency accommodation and permanent accommodation. Even providing someone with some soup and a warm jacket makes all the difference. 

I’m also taking donations for toiletries, tinned food and the like which I will deliver to The Simon Community before Christmas, let me know if you’d like to get involved with that.

Thank you for your generosity x

Title: Bryony's Fundraising for the homeless charities in Brighton

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm deeply saddened to see the level of homelessness in Manchester and by contributing to the Lifeshare site you are actively helping young people get their lives back on track and keep them off of the streets.

I'm currently working in Manchester and am fortunate enough to have a roof over my head, running hot water and food whenever I want. We take every day things like this for granted and for some poor souls through no fault of their own they have none of this.

Lifeshare understand these issues and how to address them, so by funding them you are directly helping the homeless situation in Manchester, giving hope and a future, a roof, hot water and food.

Title: Helping the homeless by zoe and ivan

Description:
Coronavirus Emergency Homeless Appeal urgently need your help. ﻿The homeless charity Alabaré is working around the clock with young people, Armed Forces Veterans, care leavers and young parents with babies who find themselves on the street. ﻿

Alabaré's Homeless Service Manager Sue remarks, "Rough sleepers do not have access to the soap and water we are all using to help protect ourselves. They do not have the means to self-isolate. The vast majority are more susceptible to illness and many have complex underlying health problems. If the virus does spread, homeless people could be amongst the first to die."

The homeless people Alabaré support are extremely vulnerable to Coronavirus; 75% of their homeless clients have underlying health issues* and many have no one else to turn to.

Major General John Stokoe CB CBE says, “In these challenging times, those who have fallen through the cracks of social care need help more than ever before. Alabaré picks these people up and gives them the support they so desperately need.”

Coronavirus is already putting huge strains on Alabaré financially. Their charity's services are facing unprecedented challenges and are putting emergency procedures in to place.

Professor Sir Deian Hopkin, Chair, Wales Remembers 1914-18 notes, “The extraordinary measures that we are taking in response to the Covid-19 would have seemed unimaginable a couple of weeks ago. There are many people suffering at this time, and Alabaré’s Coronavirus Emergency Homeless Appeal is doing its very best to provide support for a particularly vulnerable group, the many homeless people across our country. While you may be getting many requests for donations, Alabaré would be particularly grateful for your generous support at this time.”

As you would imagine their fundraising events over the next 6 months have all had to stop and they are facing an immediate loss of at least £100,000 at a time when they desperately need that money to help save lives. If they are unable to raise this money quickly, this virus could even threaten the charity's survival and that would be a disaster in and of itself.

Professor Michele Russell, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, states, "COVID-19 presents risks to the existing homeless, many are our veterans, people who have long term physical and mental health issues, also predicted that job losses will force many to the streets. The inability to self-isolate makes them particularly vulnerable. The situation is at critical level now, yet it is not unsurmountable to tackle this. It will only happen if we take measures of compassion to provide additional financial support." 

Please donate today and help Alabaré save lives.

* Statistic from 1 September 2019 - 1 March 2020.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Homeless young people, aged 16-25, stay with Centrepoint for up to two years, but they keep supporting them for another six months to make sure they can live independently.

They provide accommodation, health support and life skills to get them back into education, training and employment.

Homeless young people have different issues and different needs to adults. They're often homeless because it's not safe for them to stay at home, or family life has become too hard. We know thousands of young people sleep rough every night, but there are thousands more sleeping on sofas, floors, night buses or with strangers - the 'hidden homeless'.

No home, no bed, no security and no stability. Being homeless affects every part of your life. It's exhausting and could make mental health issues much worse. It's no wonder young people take risks to find somewhere to sleep.

A safe, warm and stable place to live is the first, crucial step for every homeless young person. Then, Centrepoint help to tackle physical and mental health issues, teach basic life skills and get them back into education, training or a job - this is the recipe for supporting homeless young people into positive and independent living.

By sponsoring a room at Centrepoint you can help a homeless young person leave homelessness behind for good. For just £12 a month you can help save lives and change lives. That's just £144 for a whole year!

Title: Emma's end youth homelessness with bodyshop

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Homelessness is becoming a bigger problem now than in previous years not aided one bit by Covid-19. The government has now lifted the eviction ban.  Many people are losing their jobs and unable to pay their rent. With gaps in the safety net and no support for renters who have built up rent arrears, people across the country are at risk of losing their home over the coming months. 

Nobody in this day and age should be without shelter, and we are coming up to the roughest time of year for homeless people. 

I want to do my bit by killing 2 birds with 1 stone. I am water fasting to reset my body, allow it to fix itself through autophagy and ensure that I am healthy. I aim to go 14 days (I have done 9 days previously), but will go longer provided I feel healthy enough. Please rest assured that I have done much research on this subject and know it to be safe for me. You do not starve provided you have sufficient fat in your body to be converted (not an issue!). 

Anything you are willing to give will be appreciated, even £1, so thank you in advance. Anyone wanting to sponsor by day can let me know and we'll see how far I can go :)

Background: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNzCt2bzyqg&list=PLtsG6wUyRJEjOcDMwNWTstVi7BPpMWcOc&index=22

Description:
Tony and I are reaching out to all our friends  to support a cause very dear to our hearts;  Alabare's Homes for Veterans. You have been most generous over the years and we hesitate to ask you again but today we are all facing a major crisis.

Many of us fortunate to live in this beautiful County have Homes,Space, Gardens, Computers, Facetime/Telephone and Television which does help relieve the pressure  but many including the homeless do not.  Alabare Homes for Veterans NOW urgently need your help.    75% of our homeless have underlying health issues and many have no one to turn to.  Rough sleepers do not have access to the soap and water we are all using to help protect ourselves. They do not have the means to self-isolate. The vast majority are more susceptible to illness and many have complex underlying mental as well as ill health problems.'  The charity has seen an 400% increase in the number of  people who have needed to self-isolate  With support from Alabaré, thankfully, many have had somewhere safe to go. In a small way by taking care of them we hope this, in a small way, does help our fantastic NHS. 

However sadly almost overnight, sources of funding have dried up. The virus is spreading, the charity are supporting more vulnerable Veterans off the street each day but without action now, a large number of homeless Veterans could die. As you know we have here in Gloucestershire our own Alabare Veterans Homes but Alabare have many Homes in the U.K. helping Veterans from our 3 Services,  Please can you help us today and help Alabaré save lives.

We fully appreciate you all have your own special charities and are most generous but today even a small donation will go such  a long way in helping us to support our Veterans who fought our battles in the past. However now we are all fighting an unseen,vicious enemy and must fight together.  Our warmest thanks if you can help our Veterans and our Homeless during this major crisis affecting our World today. 

THANKYOU!

Title: Coronavirus Emergency Homeless Appeal

Description:
My 10 year old son William has written the below inspired by the suffering of homeless people during Coronavirus.  If it touches you please make a donation to Shelter. Thanks for your generosity. 

Homeless & Hungry

I was cold, hungry and exposed to the chill which blew through the trees. You could hear the frigid wind whistling harshly across the deserted highway. The only thing you could hear was a lone bird warbling a tiny bit of hope, giving me a bit of courage on times yet to come. It made me think of all those lucky people who have a roof and a heater. It makes me feel resentful and want to curl up in a ball and die.

I couldn’t face her, she was too cruel. I think if I looked at her one more time I would burst into floods of tears. The world has become too cruel, corrupted and malevolent. All those people stick up their noses when they come near me.  But I am a person too. I shouldn’t be treated with all those nasty looks. I feel sad, lonely and alone. There is no one there for me. I truly am alone. Slowly rain started to pour down on my head.

I can’t even have my morning coffee because my friend can’t come and give me food from the restaurant because of the coronavirus stopping anyone from leaving their houses. But I am exposed to everything. I am hungry and thirsty. I might even die of the dreaded virus.

Days, months passed. I lay there starved. Then two familiar footsteps approached me. Was it my Guardian Angel? Could he bring life to my death? Was the earth finally going to listen to my pleadings? Was it true?

By William Smith, 10 years old
Title: William raising money for Homeless

The St Johns Homelessness Initiative is a joint commitment from all organisations involved in the development to contribute towards ending homelessness through; awareness-raising, inclusive employment, and fundraising. 

This is a pioneering project which has created a meaningful and sustainable model of collaboration between developers, contractors, supply chain organisations, the city Council and local charities. As far as we are aware, this is the largest single commitment from these industries towards the reduction of homelessness in the UK and we hope that it will be replicated. 

We are working with the Manchester Homelessness Partnership and Big Change MCR to ensure that our efforts and your donations are channelled to where they are most needed. Description:
I am studying Art and Design at College and I have chosen to focus on Urban Environment for my Final Major Project, specifically Homelessness in Peterborough. This is just a small part of my project and I'm partially hoping that it will work as a form of non-traditional public art. Whilst brainstorming ideas for this project, I focused on Peterborough because I have lived here most of my life meaning I have a personal attachment to this specific Urban Environment. A big issue in most urban environments is homelessness because of the overpopulation of the area, meaning it is difficult to earn money and afford a roof over your head, let alone food to eat. This is a huge problem in Peterborough so I'm using this project to start a campaign and raise awareness.

I have started this fundraising page mainly to raise awareness about Peterborough Soup Kitchen. Upon researching them recently, I have found out that they provide food and drinks for 35 - 76 people A DAY. The charity deserves the donations and if you live in or have visited Peterborough, you will know just how many unfortunate, homeless people there are on the streets. I am only asking for small donations as I can sympathise about not having a lot of spare money.

Title: Yaz's FMP: Urban Environment: Homelessness

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hello everyone!


My hand recently pledged at the As-Suffa Sisters annual conference to give some money towards helping the homeless. I say my hand pledged because I don't think my brain even processed anything before I said I'd do it 😂 I guess my encounters with the homeless in Bham city centre made me not think twice. I'll mention a couple of people I always think about if you wanted to have a read: (or if not, maybe donate through the link 😉😉)


1. Once, I saw this guy the same age as me who was selling the big issue. He didn't mind me asking him how he got homeless. He said that his mum was an alcohol/drug addict (I can't remember which one it was about 4 years ago) and he refused to pay towards her addiction as he saw it was harming her and so he got kicked out the house for this. He said he didn't want to end up begging on the streets but rather earn some money by doing something. I told him I'd give him some money but I didn't want the big issue but he felt like this was begging as I wouldn't be getting anything in return. He did accept this eventually though. I think his story affected me more because he was my age and I couldn't imagine my life being like that.


2. Another time, a man asked me for some change as he wanted a baguette but was just a few pennies short. He literally just wanted those few pennies and nothing more. I however didn't have much loose change on me so I gave him £1 but kept trying to refuse this as he said this was more than he needed for his baguette. Eventually he kept it but realised that because he stopped me, I had missed my bus. He repeatedly apologised and kept saying thank you and 'God bless you.' His genuiness and gratefulness was something else and has stuck with me til today.


I know that there are negative perceptions of homeless people. At the end of the day, it could happen to anyone and it's not necessarily anyone's fault. Sometimes we just need a little support in life which is what As-Suffa aims to do. I'd appreciate any amount of donations and if you can't donate right now, then maybe share this link so someone else can donate 😊


Thank youuuu ❤

Title: Help end a person's homelessness

Description:
Over 83,000 young people are experiencing homelessness right now.Violence, abuse, neglect and problems with mental health - young people often become homeless because it's safer to leave home than to stay. End Youth Homelessness (EYH) is a coalition of charities that provide safe and stable places for over 26,000 young people to live across the UK. 

A ground breaking report published today estimates a staggering 140,063 young people aged between 16 and 24 in Wales spent at least one night sofa surfing or rough sleeping during 2013-14, because they had nowhere else to go.


The number of young people in the UK who have slept rough at least one night during 2013-14 to be 1.27 million people, nearly 1 in 5 (17%) of all young people in the UK. It suggests that homelessness generally in the United Kingdom is massively underreported – it estimates that 83,000 homeless young people were accommodated by local authorities or homelessness services in the UK during 2013-14, against a UK government figure of just 26,852.


Therefore, for reasons such as this, were fundraising for the End Youth Homelessness charity and sleeping rough for five days on just £1 a day to help tackle this ongoing issue.


Join us sisters on our journey!


Jodie and Zoey

Title: Sophie's Helping the Homeless in Cardiff at Christmas

Description:
Growing up in the Bristol area, I remember homelessness being prevalent in the 90s. I used to find it very upsetting and so, every Christmas time, with my friends, we would go carol singing in order to raise money for Bristol's homeless. For a while, homelessness appeared to lessen, but in recent years it is definitely on the up again. I now have children of my own and now, when we see a homeless person, they find it extremely upsetting and worrying. They are little young for carol singing.. So I wracked my brains.. What could we do instead, something all of us could be involved in, something that, on top of maybe raising a little money, would also help the local area. Then it dawned on me. Litter picking. We happen to litter pick a lot anyway, but to do it for a cause gives us an extra motivation! So. This is the plan. We will litter pick AT LEAST once a week between now (10th September) until Christmas. 

We really hope you might consider sponsoring us. It would mean a lot! 

Thank you for reading. 

Alex, Ethan & Felix.

This is a pioneering project which has created a meaningful and sustainable model of collaboration between developers, contractors, supply chain organisations, the city Council and local charities. As far as we are aware, this is the largest single commitment from these industries towards the reduction of homelessness in the UK and we hope that it will be replicated. 

We are working with the Manchester Homelessness Partnership and Big Change MCR to ensure that our efforts and your donations are channelled to where they are most needed. This fund will support potentially hundreds of people who are homeless in Manchester and will prevent more people from becoming homeless.

Title: I'm Supporting my Daughter Haleema to raising money Orphan Children's

Description:
We've all seen homeless people on the streets.  We've all felt sad for them, wondered how we can help them or wondered why they don't help themselves.

My job brings me into contact with lots of homeless people.  Some sofa surf from house to house - others are totally alone and sleep on the streets.  Sometimes out in the rain or sub-zero temperatures.  I get to meet these people, to hear their stories and try to help.  Most have mental health problems, addictions and tragic backgrounds.  The answer to their problems isn't easy.

Without a doubt, homelessness is on the rise.  That's apparent from a glance around any city's streets.  

This Christmas I want to help by raising a donation to Shelter and raising awareness of the problem.  I'll be holding a coffee morning at home on 9th December.  Please come for coffee and cake, buy a raffle ticket or take part in my chocolate tombola.

If you can't make it, you could still help by making a cake, donating a raffle prize or chocolate for the tombola or making a donation through this page.

Thank you for your support and I really hope you can join me.

Title: Ruby Skyes fundraiser for homeless

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I started running again a few years ago after doing couch to 5k about 10 years ago but stopped fairly soon after reaching 5k as I got terrible shin splints and running wasn’t fun at all! I went back to the gym about 4 years ago and through uphill max treadmill walking and spinning on the gym bike I lost 3 stone. I started running with Griffithstown Harriers after my neighbour said I ought to join a club. I stumbled across The Barkley Marathons Netflix documentary and got hooked on what we’re capable of achieving in endurance running. I ran 1688 miles last year and climbed up over 150k feet, that’s 5 Everests. I did 3 32 mile Ultra marathons around the Brecon Beacons, the Black Mountains and Snowdon ( I didn’t complete that one, did 30 miles of it but will post about that later), and a mountain marathon around the Beacons last year. I haven’t even done a road marathon yet, apart from a training one for the Ultras. 

I was a student in Cardiff between 1982-85. Back then there may have been perhaps 3 or 4 people on the streets asking for money. I’ve recently been back and cannot believe the scale of homelessness now starkly evident. Every closed shopfront has a tent in it on St Mary’s Street and Queen Street and many other places too. That is why I want to raise money for The Huggard.

I did the Virtual London Marathon today  3rd October 2021 doing theAbergavenny 3Peaks plus about 4 extra miles and 5000ft of elevation.Please chuck a few quid in the pot if you can thank you!!!

Title: Appeal to help the homeless in Glasgow.

Description:
Having not gone over a month without a drink for nearly 40 years, this really is quite a challenge!

It seems the number of homeless people on our streets is increasing exponentially. With winter upon us you can only try and imagine the extreme cold and often hazardous life for someone with no home. The association with alcoholism, and the needlessness of alcohol in our lives made this feel an appropriate challenge and a good opportunity to raise funds.

Myself and Seth East intend to give up all alcoholic drinks for the first 100 days of 2020, and also to encourage the staff and customers of Kileys Karpets to do part or all of the same, and then donate the money saved to Centrepoint. Or sponsor us for doing so. If I fall off the wagon (I won't!!), I will double what ever sum is raised. 

We have chosen to support Centrepoint as their aim is to end youth homelessness. By supporting young people, they capture this vulnerable population before they become the entrenched homeless you see every day.

Centrepoint is the UK’s leading youth homelessness charity supporting 16-25 year olds. Providing homeless young people with accommodation, health support and life skills to get them back into education, training and employment. With this hoslistic model, 88% of the young people Centrepoint supports move on positively.

Title: Charlotte's page

Description:
I have recently returned home from Bangladesh volunteering for a charity called Y Care International.

On my first day of being home I noticed a homeless man sitting near the airport. We live in one of the richest places in the world and still we have a large percentage of people living on the street. Study shows that over 307,000 people are living on the street or in poor housing conditions. Further more over 150,000 of those people are living in London. One in every 59 people are homeless in London. Something has to change.

Last year crisis helped over 11,000 people on their journey out of homelessness. In 2016/2017 1400 people progressed into external education or a paid job.

It is very important that we tackle this issue, for in the next decade homelessness is believed to be raised by 75%.  Unless we and the government do something about it, it could be one of our loved ones, friends, family members, children.

We are a group of second year students from Glasgow Caledonian
University taking part in a community project as part of our Triple E module. We have collaborated with Simon Community Scotland, a local charity aiming to eradicate homelessness in the Glasgow area. We are creating essential care bags containing items that are critical for those who are vulnerable. We aim to raise money to enable us to donate a large amount of bags to Simon Community Scotland who will distribute them to the homeless in our city.

Description: Alabaré urgently need your help. The homeless people Alabaré support are extremely vulnerable to Coronavirus; 75% of our homeless clients have underlying health issues* and many have no one else to turn to.'Rough sleepers do not have access to the soap and water we are all using to help protect ourselves. They do not have the means to self-isolate. The vast majority are more susceptible to illness and many have complex underlying health problems. If the virus does spread, homeless people could be amongst the first to die.' Sue, Alabaré Homeless Service Manager. Please donate today and help Alabaré save lives.

Description:
“He is not a believer whose stomach is filled while the neighbour to his side goes hungry.” (Bukhari, Muslim)


£70 - Provide a family-of-six with enough nutritious food to last them the whole month of Ramadan.


£30 - Provide a  family with 2 bread deliveries per week for 2 months.


Tonight, one in nine people will go to bed hungry; vulnerable people are often given no choice but to eat food without nutrients, eat insufficiently, or not eat at all. With the continuing spread of COVID-19, the search for work is even more risky, especially for the most at-risk families.
According to the World Food Programme (WFP), more children die each year as a result of under nutrition than malaria, AIDS and tuberculosis combined. A staggering 45% of all deaths among children under 5 are caused by malnutrition.


Change starts here. This Ramadan, donate to our food fund and allow us to support vulnerable people struggling for food, whenever and wherever they need it.
Donate to our food fund today.
Title: Aamir's Feeding the homeless through Ramadan

Description:
It's our FINAL fundraiser for Homeless Oxfordshire so we'd love to see as much participation as possible! By reaching this target, we would've raised an incredible £25,000!

What better way to smash this target than to provide a fantastic raffle for you to get involved in, with prize winners to be announced at Zoodlefest, this Saturday 31st July 2021.

Tickets are £2 each, please pop your name and how many tickets you would like when making your donation. Good luck!

Homeless Oxfordshire is the largest provider of supported temporary accommodation for homeless adults in the county. Each night we accommodate 220 people. But we are more than bricks and mortar. Through 11 innovative projects, we provide the person-centred support people need to recover from homelessness for good.
Title: Zoodlefest Fundraiser - Homeless Oxfordshire

Description:
Throughout May Arnold & Porter are running a fundraising competition. The office has been split into three teams and we have a month to raise as much money as we can for our charity. We are raising money for Single Homeless Project. 

Single Homeless Project (SHP), is a London-wide charity working to prevent homelessness and help vulnerable and socially excluded people to transform their lives. Each day across all 32 London boroughs, staff work with individuals to tackle the underlying causes of homelessness, such as poor mental health or drug and alcohol dependency. From supporting people in crisis to helping people take the final steps towards independence and employment, SHP make a difference to 8,000 lives every year.

We have lots of fundraising activities planned throughout the month and we are really grateful for any donations!

Title: Marc's MW Sports homeless sleep

Description:
Thanks for visiting my page

This month I will be challenging myself to row 200km on a rowing machine to raise money for Huggard. This means I'll be covering an average of about 10km every night in the run-up to Christmas!!

Those of you who live near Cardiff will likely have heard of Huggard - it is located just next to Cardiff central train station and for 30 years it has provided food, warmth, support and shelter for the homeless of South Wales. 

After the year we have had, there is no better time to support such a fantastic charity 

As an extra incentive, every penny you donate up to £500 will be matched by the organisation I work for so it’s a fantastic way to raise money for a hugely important charity

And every penny counts...

    •    £5 will buy 3 meals for someone who is sleeping rough.

    •    £10 pays for a bed for the night.  

    •    £25 is what it costs for someone to work with a person struggling with homelessness to help them claim the benefits they are owed and find more long term accommodation.  

    •    £47 pays for emergency accommodation for a week. 

Please give what you can and wish us luck as we take this on - thank you!

Title: Dan's 200km row for homelessness

Description:
I am running a Christmas collection for The Clock Tower Sanctuary in Brighton.

They are the only drop-in day centre in Brighton & Hove for 16-to-25 year olds who are homeless or insecurely housed. They provide space and emotional support, as well as access to essential services.

As a small charity, they rely entirely on donations to keep services running. Many of their fundraising events have been cancelled this year due to the pandemic.

They provide the everyday things that young homeless people need, like somewhere to shower, do laundry, eat a healthy meal, use computers and get post.

By helping to meet these practical needs, young homeless people can focus on their futures and potential. Christmas is a particularly difficult time to be homeless, as most of these people have no family and a very limited support network.

Young people have been particularly hit hard by the pandemic and those in a vulnerable situation now face an even more challenging time, with less opportunities and chances to escape.

My situation when I was 16-25 was a lot different to those I want to help; for me Brighton was, and can still be, a place of safety and fun; a stark contrast to vulnerable young people’s experiences.

The Clock Tower Sanctuary would appreciate your kind donation, big or small.

Thank you.

Tim x
Title: Christmas Collection - Clock Tower Homeless Shelter

CharityName: Soup Kitchen at the American International Church
Description:
Joining "Walk in the Footsteps of the Homeless", Efficiency & Effectiveness Team of NHS Property Services is raising money for The Soup Kitchen London. 

The 4.5miles walk has been designed to give us an idea of what the average rough sleeper has to endure to find food, clothing, safety and shelter each day. 

Carrying weighted rucksack filled with supplies, we will also distribute warm clothing, snacks and drinks along our walk. 

Your donation will mean a lot for The Soup Kitchen in helping them supporting the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London. 

Thank you!

--------------------------------------------------------

From the Soup Kitchen:

Many of you have called, emailed or messaged to ask about how we are coping with COVID-19 and the impact it has had on our organisation. Firstly, let me say thank you for the outpouring of support we've received. It's always a heart-warming feeling to know that we have so many incredible supporters. Last week, in light of the Coronavirus, we made the difficult decision to offer a takeaway-only food service to guests rather than their usual sit-down meal. As most of you know, we take a huge amount of pride in the fact that we offer not just a warm meal to our guests, but also a safe and warm space off the streets for them for the hours they're with us. As we considered the health risks we decided that it would be prudent to only offer a takeaway food service for the foreseeable future.Absolutely any donation will have a huge impact on our services. Thank you for helping us support the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate in London!
Title: Soup Kitchen London Emergency Appeal

Description:
Did you know St Basil's house over 500 young people every single night across our 35 supported accommodation schemes in Birmingham, Bromsgrove, Solihull, Redditch, Bromsgrove, Kidderminster, Walsall, Sandwell and now Leamington Spa? Every day, St Basils are running at a deficit and sadly were short of £5 per day per young person staying in one of our projects. 

I am supporting the organisation because people can become homeless for many reasons and the effects of homelessness can be devastating. 

Home means a future, once people have a stable home it allows people to flourish. Let's support St Basil's to achieve its aims.
Title: Saltley Academy Big Sleepout!

Description:
The above photo is from 2018...the last time I slept out for Herts Young Homeless.  This year Buyagift is sponsoring the St Albans sleepout in support of our charity partner Herts Young Homeless so I'll be sleeping out again. 

Along with a lump sum donation from the company we will be sending volunteers to help out on the night - but most importantly a team of intrepid fundraisers (including me) have committed themselves to sleeping out to raise awareness as well as much needed cash for this awesome charity.
Title: Fundraising for Herts Young Homeless Group

Description:
Winter 2021-22 is going to be extra tough.

Wycombe Homeless Connection needs our help to make sure there will be help and hope this winter for anyone who needs it.

Locally, efforts to keep everyone in have just ended and more people will need a safe place to stay this winter.

The huge challenge they face is keeping everyone who doesnt have a home off the street, in suitable accommodation, with everything they need to stay healthy and well, while helping them find a more suitable, more permanent home. All this while there continues to be a severe shortage of suitable and affordable homes meaning moving on from emergency accommodation can be incredibly difficult.

The good news is because of your support, WHC can be here to help.
Title: Wycombe Homeless Connection's Big Sleepout 2021: At Home

Description:
I'm raising money for Bromley Homeless as I believe everyone deserves a home. After over a decade working with the homeless, Larry’s story is typical of many of the people I meet: 

“I lost everything in the pandemic including my job, my home and my connection with my kids. It wasn't possible to sleep on the buses or pop into a church for a cup of tea. I was reduced to sleeping in woodlands and abandoned lock-ups for six months, until I found [Bromley Homeless]. I will never forget everything you have done for me. Thank you." - LarryB, aged 51.
Title: Fundraising for Bromley Homeless this Winter

Description:
I'm raising money for Bromley Homeless. Here's Larry's story which any one of us might identify with, particularly after the past 18 months in the pandemic. Any sum you can spare will be spent on supporting someone in need or directly bringing comfort or relief to their time of hardship. Thank you.

"I lost everything in the pandemic including my job, my home and my connection with my kids. It wasn't possible to sleep on the buses or pop into a church for a cup of tea. I was reduced to sleeping in woodlands and abandoned lock-ups for six months, until I found [Bromley Homeless]. I will never forget everything you have done for me. Thank you." - LarryB, aged 51
Title: Fundraising for Bromley Homeless this Winter

Description:
I hate to see all these homeless people out on the streets. I think it's just so unfair! How do we have a home and they don't?!

Just because we have more money than them and the London housing prices are inflated, it doesn't mean they should live out on the streets.

I feel I want to give to a charity... and, as much as I do, I don't think an 8 years old kid should have to do that, to get the people off the streets, into homes.
Title: Adna's Zak's Act of Kindness

Description:
This year I am supporting the UCKG Help Centre to help raise donations to support their charitable work. I will be going out on Xmas Day to donate warm food and gifts to rough sleepers around London!

1. Food Bank - Helping many families keep food on the table especially during these hard moments


2. Soup Kitchen - Providing members of the society, homeless people, people sleeping rough with hot and warm food.


3. Night Angels - Providing homeless people, people sleeping rough with essential hygiene products such as; Toothpaste, toothbrush, soap, deodorant etc. As well as warm food and sleeping products 


4. The 24 Hour Helpline - A telephone line providing support for those who need.

5. Give Warmth - Providing the homeless with warm clothing such as; blankets, coats, socks, scarfs etc. To keep warm during these cold winters nights

The funds raised will help support the general work of the UCKG Help Centre and will also help these 5 projects mentioned above to be kept alive!

So lets join together to help the UCKG Help Centre so that more people can be supported and helped during these tough times .This something that's close to my heart as through these works I also found help so let's give others the same opportunity.
Title: Robert's Xmas Homelessness Challenge

Description: We provide support for rough sleepers, homeless and vulnerably-housed people in East Kent. Our centre in Canterbury is open 7 days a week providing services including: meals, laundry, change of clothes, mental health support, art activities and advice and advocacy. Our objective is to help people tackle their issues, access accommodation and find the motivation to move towards personal recovery and independent living. This includes mentoring; helping people maintain accommodation, and mental health support after they have moved on.
Title: Please donate to help the homeless

Description:
Help Street Zero to once and for all end rough sleeping in Newcastle by 2022.

We all have a moral right to decent housing, yet right now some people in our city are homeless.

All people should be treated with dignity and humanity. Your support will make sure everyone can be provided with a safe and stable place to live for the long-term.

Every penny donated to the Street Zero Fund goes to those most in need of help. It will support them to overcome some of the struggles they face and help them move away from a life on the streets. 

Donate today and make a real difference to someone's life.
Title: Angel Of The North Song For The Homeless

Description:
Melody & Alexander will be sleeping  under the stars on 19th November 2021 (no matter the weather! ) in order to raise awareness and money for homeless veterans.

This cause is important to them, since their aunt and uncle along with their cousin are all soldiers. 

Help us to help these sweet and selfless twins to raise  money for something close to their hearts xx

All funds raised from Petals for Peace will go to Alabaré Homes for Veterans, supporting homeless and vulnerable Veterans who are particularly vulnerable to Coronavirus.We are hoping to get 1,000 households to display Petals of Peace and each donate £5 to this JustGiving page. Our target is to raise £5,000 for our work with homeless and vulnerable Veterans.
Title: Raising money for homeless veterans

Description:
Story

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My name is Shane and I’m 8 years old. Ever since I was four I’ve been passionate about helping the homeless. I learnt  about it from the news little adverts at first. I realised that people were sleeping in railways, dark alleyways, on the streets even when it’s raining or snowing  and in dark tunnels.  People were dying on the streets because they dont have any blankets or any where to sleep,  nothing to drink or eat.  So I leapt into action and gathered all my courage to save money and help the homeless.  I started by donating food to the food banks. 

I’m asking for donations for Barnabus in Manchester, they’re a Christian Homeless charity and this is their 30th Anniversary year. Barnabus help people off the streets into a home,  I have chosen this charity because their mission means so much to me, and it’s the second time I’m fundraising for them. The first time was in February this year for my birthday and I was able to raise a lot of money thanks to people like you to support their work. I also donated a lot of items that they needed to help people during lockdown.

 I have also given up eating chocolates which I love for a whole month so I can raise more money to get the homeless people off the streets this winter.  

I like helping the homeless because I believe “Everyone Must Have A Home.”    In the past I have donated food and raised money for the Narrowgate 24/7 Homeless Shelter in Salford. I raised money for the Guide Dogs. Sent my birthday money in 2019 to buy sweets and biscuits for children in Kenya, and did a donation for a school building fund to help children in Kenya 

I was also interviewed on BBC Radio Manchester, last September 2020 about why I like to help the homeless.  My answer was, “EVERYONE MUST HAVE A HOME”. 

My little brother who is also four and goes to the same school as me has joined me and we are determined to raise as much money as we can to help the homeless this winter. We want to help as many homeless people as we can, but we cannot do this alone and need your help so will you please help us?

Thank you

Shane Plange

Title: Helping homeless people in Bath

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page supporting Shelter UK

Many of us in the team live in central areas where the homeless crisis is increasing dramatically. As employees of a Housing Association we feel the impact of this at work as well. The Property Services team have decided they wanted to take steps to help support this worthy cause..... literally!

On 8th September instead of taking our normal journey home, we will be walking from our office in Lewisham to St Paul's Cathedral. During our journey we will be talking to rough sleepers ensure they are aware of local support available to them, such as StreetLink and Centrepoint as well as what Shelter can offer.
